{{Infobox song | name = Deportee (Plane Wreck at Los Gatos) | artist = [[Woody Guthrie]] | written = {{Start date|1948}} | genre = [[Protest song]] | lyricist = Woody Guthrie | composer = Martin Hoffman }} "'''Deportee (Plane Wreck at Los Gatos)'''" is a [[protest song]] with [[lyrics]] by [[Woody Guthrie]] and music by Martin Hoffman detailing the [[1948 Los Gatos DC-3 crash|January 28, 1948 crash]] of a plane near Los Gatos Canyon,{{cite book |author=Klein, Joe. |year=1999 |title=Woody Guthrie: A Life |publisher=Delta |isbn=0-385-33385-4}} {{convert|20|mi}} west of [[Coalinga]] in [[Fresno County, California]], United States.{{cite web |title=60th anniversary of "Plane Wreck at Los Gatos (Deportee)" |publisher=[[Indybay]] |url=https://www.indybay.org/newsitems/2008/01/30/18475895.php |accessdate=2009-10-16}}{{cite web |title=DC3 Aircraft Crash Site in Los Gatos Canyon |publisher=Three Rocks Research |url=http://www.picacho.org/interest/dc3-site.html |accessdate=2009-10-16 |archivedate=2014-03-20 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140320011329/http://www.picacho.org/interest/dc3-site.html}} The crash occurred in [[Los Gatos Creek (Fresno County, California)|Los Gatos Canyon]] and not in the town of [[Los Gatos, California|Los Gatos]] itself, which is in [[Santa Clara County, California|Santa Clara County]], approximately 150 miles away. Guthrie was inspired to write the song by what he considered the racist mistreatment of the passengers before and after the accident. The crash resulted in the deaths of 32 people, 4 Americans and 28 [[Migrant worker|migrant farm workers]] who were being deported from California back to [[Mexico]]. == History == [[File:Woody Guthrie 2.jpg|right|thumb|Woody Guthrie.]] The genesis of "Deportee (Plane Wreck at Los Gatos)" reportedly occurred when Guthrie was struck by the fact that radio and newspaper coverage of the Los Gatos plane crash did not give the victims' names, but instead referred to them merely as "deportees." Guthrie lived in New York City at the time, and none of the deportees' names were printed in the January 29, 1948, ''[[The New York Times|New York Times]]'' report, only those of the flight crew and the security guard.{{cite web|title=Los Gatos Canyon Plane Crash, Fresno County, California|publisher=Eastern Mojave Vegetation|url=http://www.schweich.com/geoCAFreLosGatosCynCrash.html|accessdate=2009-10-16}} However, the local newspaper, ''[[The Fresno Bee]]'', covered the tragedy extensively and listed all of the known names of the deportees.{{cite book|last=Kulczyk|first=David|title=Death in California – The Bizarre, Freakish, and Just Curious Ways People Die in the Golden State|year=2009|publisher=Craven Street Books|location=Fresno, CA|isbn=978-1-884995-57-6|page=80}} Unaware of the extensive local coverage of the disaster, Guthrie responded with a poem, which, when it was first written, featured only rudimentary musical accompaniment, with Guthrie chanting the song rather than singing it. In the poem, Guthrie assigned symbolic names to the dead: "Goodbye to my Juan, goodbye Rosalita; adiós, mis amigos, Jesús y María..."{{cite web|title=Deeportee (Plane Wreck at Los gatos) lyrics|publisher=The Official Woody Guthrie Website|url=http://www.woodyguthrie.org/Lyrics/Deportee.htm|accessdate=2009-09-27}} A decade later, Guthrie's poem was set to music and given a haunting melody by a schoolteacher named Martin Hoffman. Shortly after, [[folk singer]] [[Pete Seeger]], a friend of Woody Guthrie, began performing the song at concerts, and it was Seeger's rendition that popularized the song during this time. It has been suggested by the Three Rocks Research website that, in fact, "Deportee (Plane Wreck at Los Gatos)" betrays Guthrie's lack of understanding regarding the [[Bracero Program]]. The program was a series of laws and diplomatic agreements created by the [[United States Congress|U.S. Congress]] in 1942, that permitted Mexican farm laborers (or Braceros) to work in the United States due to the severe labor shortages caused by World War II. Under the terms of the program, the labor contractors were expected to provide transportation to and from the Mexican border, with the [[Immigration and Naturalization Service|U.S. Immigration Service]] being required to repatriate the Mexican citizens if the contractor defaulted. As such, the "deportation" of Braceros in this fashion was simply a way of meeting the obligations of the program—although some newspapers, e.g., the New York Times, did refer to the braceros as "deportees". However, the presence in the song of the lines, "Some of us are illegal, and some are not wanted/Our work contract's out and we have to move on." suggests that Guthrie did in fact understand the workings of the Bracero Program. Furthermore, it could be argued that Guthrie's song is less about the program itself and more a comment on the attitude of American society and the media towards the Mexican farm laborers. In addition to being a [[lament]] for the braceros killed in the crash, the opening lines of "Deportee (Plane Wreck at Los Gatos)":
The crops are all in and the peaches are rott'ning, The oranges piled in their [[creosote]] dumps."
are another protest by Guthrie. At the time, government policies paid farmers to destroy their crops in order to keep farm production and prices high.{{cite web |title=Mark Hammond: Chapel Talk |publisher=The Irene DuPont Library |url=http://library.standrews-de.org/lists/ChapelTalks/CTFaculty/HammondCT-01-7-2004.pdf |accessdate=2009-10-16}} {{Dead link |date=October 2010 |bot=H3llBot}} Guthrie felt that it was wrong to render food inedible by poisoning it in a world where hungry people lived. "Deportee (Plane Wreck at Los Gatos)" has been described by journalist [[Joe Klein]] as "the last great song he [Guthrie] would write, a memorial to the nameless migrants 'all scattered like dry leaves' in Los Gatos Canyon." The song has been recorded many times, often under a variety of other titles, including "Deportees", "Ballad of the Deportees", "Deportee Song", "Plane Crash at Los Gatos" and "Plane Wreck at Los Gatos (Deportee)". == Recordings == {{example farm|section|date=September 2018}} The song has been recorded by many artists, including: * [[James Talley]] on "Woody Guthrie and Songs of my Oklahoma revision.text:
{{pp-move-indef}} {{islamophobia}} {{Use mdy dates|date=September 2016}}
In July 2010, [[Terry Jones (pastor)|Terry Jones]], the pastor of the Christian [[Dove World Outreach Center]] in [[Gainesville, Florida]], U.S., announced he would burn 200 Qurans on the 2010 anniversary of the [[September 11 attacks]]. He gained media coverage, resulting in international outrage over his plans and pleas from world leaders to cancel the event. Jones's threat sparked protests in the Middle East and Asia, in which at least 20 people were killed. In early September 2010, Jones cancelled and pledged never to burn a Quran.<ref>[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/39113743/ns/us_news-security/ Pastor Terry Jones: 'We will not burn the Quran' - US news - Security - msnbc.com]. MSNBC (November 9, 2010). Retrieved April 30, 2011.</ref>
Nevertheless, on March 20, 2011, Jones held a "trial of the Quran" in his Gainesville church. Finding the scriptures guilty of "crimes against humanity," the Quran was burned in the church sanctuary.<ref name=Gainesville_Dove_denies>[http://www.gainesville.com/article/20110401/ARTICLES/110409944/1169?Title=Dove-World-denies-it-s-responsible-for-violence-over-Quran-burning Gainesville's Dove World Outreach Center denied it is responsible for violence in Afghanistan over its burning of the Quran], ''Gainesville.com'' (April 1, 2011). Retrieved April 30, 2011.</ref> Protesters in the northern [[Afghanistan]] city of [[Mazar-i-Sharif]] and elsewhere [[2011 Mazar-i-Sharif attack|attacked the United Nations Assistance Mission]], killing at least 30 people, including at least seven [[United Nations]] workers, and injuring at least 150 people.<ref name="killings">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/02/world/asia/02afghanistan.html?_r=1&hp |title=Afghans Angry Over Florida Quran Burning Kill U.N. Staff |work=The New York Times |author=Rod Nordland |date=April 1, 2011}}</ref><ref>[http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/asiapcf/04/05/afghanistan.protests/ Protests continue in Afghanistan against Quran burning – CNN.com]. Edition.cnn.com (April 5, 2011). Retrieved April 30, 2011.</ref><ref>[http://www.presstv.ir/detail/173584.html PressTV – Afghans continue protests over Qur'an desecration]. Presstv.ir (April 7, 2011). Retrieved April 30, 2011.</ref> Jones disclaimed any responsibility. Norwegian, Swedish, Nepalese and Romanian nationals were among the UN workers killed.<ref>[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1372442/Pastor-Terry-Jones-defiant-Koran-burning-led-2-UN-staff-beheaded.html Pastor Terry Jones defiant after his Quran-burning led to 2 UN staff being beheaded]. Dailymail.co.uk (February 4, 2011). Retrieved April 30, 2011.</ref> The killing of two US soldiers by an Afghan policeman on 4 April 2011 was attributed to anger over the burning of the Quran.<ref name="BBC News">{{cite news |publisher=BBC News |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-21774684 |title=The Afghan 'green-on-blue' attacker seen as a hero |date=March 29, 2013}}</ref> American news analysts criticized and blamed [[Hamid Karzai]], President of Afghanistan, for drawing attention to the Quran burning.<ref>[http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Asia-South-Central/2011/0405/Why-did-Karzai-spotlight-Terry-Jones-s-Quran-burning "Why did Karzai spotlight Terry Jones's Quran burning?"], ''Christian Science Monitor'' (April 5, 2011). Retrieved April 30, 2011.</ref>
==Terry Jones== {{further|Dove World Outreach Center|Terry Jones (pastor)}} Terry Jones was born in October 1951 in [[Cape Girardeau, Missouri]].<ref name="A whirlwind">{{Cite news |url=http://www.gainesville.com/article/20100911/ARTICLES/100919867/1002?p=all&tc=pgall |title=A whirlwind of attention later, Dove World's pastor remains on the fringe |author1=Chad Smith |author2=Kimberly C. Moore |date=September 11, 2010 |publisher=The Gainesville Sun |accessdate=September 12, 2010}}</ref> He attended college for two years, worked at a hotel, and joined the now defunct [[Maranatha Campus Ministries]].<ref name="A whirlwind"/> He moved to Cologne, Germany, where in 1981 he founded a charismatic church, the Christian Community of Cologne (CGK).<ref name="A whirlwind"/><ref name="der spiegel">{{cite web <!-- old |url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/0,1518,716409,00.html--> |url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/islamophobe-s-past-in-germany-terry-jones-accused-of-spiritual-abuse-at-cologne-church-a-716409.html |title=Islamophobe's Past in Germany: Terry Jones Accused of 'Spiritual Child Abuse' at Cologne Church |publisher=Der Spiegel |first=Yassin |last=Musharbash |author2=Dominik Peters |date=September 12, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120912094127/http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/islamophobe-s-past-in-germany-terry-jones-accused-of-spiritual-abuse-at-cologne-church-a-716409.html |archivedate=September 12, 2012 |accessdate=September 20, 2016}}</ref>
Jones received an [[honorary degree]] from an [[unaccredited]] theology school in 1983, and began using the title "Doctor." He was fined for this misuse of a credential title by a German administrative court.<ref name="A whirlwind"/><ref name="fringe">{{Cite news|agency=Associated Press|title=Pastor on Fringe of US Christian Life|date=September 8, 2010|author= Rachel Zoll|url=http://www.boston.com/news/nation/articles/2010/09/08/fla_pastor_on_fringe_of_us_christian_life/?page=2|publisher=The Boston Globe}}</ref> By the late [[2000s (decade)|2000s]], the CGK grew to have a membership of approximately 800–1000.<ref name="der spiegel"/> According to the German magazine, ''Der Spiegel'', the congregation kicked Jones out in 2008 due to the "climate of fear and control" that he employed, which included elements of "brainwashing" and telling congregants to beat their children with rods.<ref name="der spiegel"/> He was accused of improper use of church funds, and forcing congregants to labor for free.<ref name="der spiegel"/> A leader of the Cologne church said Jones did not "project the biblical values and Christianity, but always made himself the center of everything." Others accused him of being violent and fanatical.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/09/08/quranburning-pastors-form_n_709878.html |title=Quran-Burning Pastor's Former German Church Denounces Him: He's 'Violent And Fanatical' |date=September 9, 2010 |accessdate=February 4, 2011 |publisher=''[[The Huffington Post]]'' |first=Niels |last=Sorrells}}</ref> ''[[Deutsche Presse-Agentur]]'' reported that church members said Jones ran the Cologne church like a [[cult]], using psychological pressure.<ref>{{cite news |publisher=Religion News Service |date=September 8, 2010 |author=Niels Sorrells |title= Pastor's Former German Church Denounces Him |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/09/08/quranburning-pastors-form_n_709878.html}}</ref>
Between 2001 and 2008, Jones served as the part-time pastor of the [[Gainesville, Florida]] church Dove World Outreach, frequently traveling back and forth between Germany and the United States.<ref name="A whirlwind"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.doveworld.org/ |title=Dove World Outreach Center |publisher=doveworld.org |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040607044638/http://www.doveworld.org/ |archivedate=June 7, 2004 |deadurl=yes |accessdate=September 11, 2010 |df=mdy }}</ref> Jones assumed full-time duties at Dove World Outreach in 2008 after leaving the German church.<ref name="A whirlwind"/> By September 2010, Dove World was said to have 50 members,<ref name="bbc2010-11-07"/> with about 30 members reportedly attending services.<ref name="A whirlwind"/>
In 2010 Jones published ''Islam Is of the Devil'', a polemic that claims [[Islam]] promotes violence, and that Muslims want to impose [[sharia law]] in the United States.<ref name=Russell>{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/terry-jones-pastor-burn-koran-day/story?id=11575665|title=Who Is Terry Jones? Pastor Behind 'Burn a Quran Day': Controversial Florida Pastor Preaches 'Islam Is of the Devil'|publisher=ABC News|first=Russell|last=Goldman|date=September 7, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|author=Jones, Terry|title=Islam Is of the Devil|publisher=Creation House, A Strang Company|location=Lake Mary, Florida|isbn=1-61638-172-8|page=176}}</ref> After Jones announced the Quran burning, the German Evangelical Alliance denounced his theological statements and his craving for attention.<ref name="German Evangelical">{{cite web|url=http://www.die-evangelikalen.de/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=52:deutsche-evangelische-allianz-distanziert-sich-von-der-verbrennung-eines-korans&catid=1:news&Itemid=45|title=German Evangelical Alliance distanced themselves from the burning of a Quran|language=German|access-date=September 8, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718230310/http://www.die-evangelikalen.de/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=52:deutsche-evangelische-allianz-distanziert-sich-von-der-verbrennung-eines-korans&catid=1:news&Itemid=45#|archive-date=July 18, 2011|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
Following an invitation from the [[English Defence League]], Jones considered attending a rally in [[Luton]] in the [[United Kingdom|U.K.]] in February 2011 to share his views. The anti-fascist group [[Hope not Hate]] petitioned the [[Home Secretary]] to ban Jones from entering the country.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-11977945 |title=Koran-protest pastor Terry Jones invited to UK rally |work=BBC News |date= December 12, 2010 |accessdate=December 12, 2010}}</ref> In January 2011 the [[Home Secretary]] announced that Jones would be [[List of individuals banned from entering the United Kingdom|refused entry to the UK]] 'for the public good'.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-12231832|title=Koran-protest US pastor Terry Jones excluded from UK |work=BBC News |date=December 19, 2011}}</ref>
Jones' actions have prompted a religious group to place a $1.2 million bounty on his head; [[Hezbollah]], a Lebanese political party and militant group, has announced a $2 million bounty.<ref>[http://www.freep.com/article/20110420/NEWS02/104200407/Metro-interfaith-leaders-unite-against-Quran-burning-pastor Metro interfaith leaders to unite against Quran-burning pastor|Detroit Free Press]. freep.com (April 20, 2011). Retrieved April 30, 2011.</ref><ref>[http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/opinion/americas-south-is-the-land-of-contradictions/story-e6frg6zo-1226039601791 "America's south is the land of contradictions"], ''The Australian'' (April 16, 2011). Retrieved April 30, 2011.</ref>
On April 22, 2011, Jones planned to visit the [[Islamic Center of America]] in [[Dearborn, Michigan]] to protest sharia but was arrested, tried and jailed.<ref>[http://www.pressandguide.com/articles/2011/04/19/news/doc4dadbde7c5553441250370.txt?viewmode=4 Terry Jones’ planned visit sparks fears of violence, hopes for solidarity – News]. Press and Guide. Retrieved April 30, 2011.</ref><ref>Brand, Oralandar. (April 23, 2011) [https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/terry-jones-says-he-will-file-a-lawsuit-against-mich-county-prosecutors-office/2011/04/23/AFLgDSYE_story.html "Terry Jones says he will file a lawsuit against Mich. county prosecutor’s office"], ''The Washington Post. Retrieved April 30, 2011.</ref> Local authorities had required him either to post a $45,000 "peace bond" to cover Dearborn's cost if Jones was attacked by extremists or to go to trial. Jones contested that requirement, and the jury voted to require the posting of a $1 "peace bond", but Jones and his co-pastor Wayne Sapp continued to refuse to pay. They were held briefly in jail, while claiming violation of First Amendment rights. That night Jones was released by the court.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.freep.com/article/20110422/NEWS02/110422014/Terry-Jones-goes-free-1-bond-after-jailing-judge-bars-him-from-mosque-3-years |title=Terry Jones goes free on $1 bond after jailing; judge bars him from mosque for 3 years | Detroit Free Press |publisher=freep.com |accessdate=September 2, 2013}}</ref> On November 11, 2011, Wayne County Circuit Court Judge Robert Ziolkowski vacated the "breach of peace" ruling against Terry Jones and Wayne Sapp on the grounds that they were denied due process. Both men's criminal records have since been expunged.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thomasmore.org/press-releases/2011/11/victory-pastor-jones-court-rules-pastor-s-constitutional-rights-were-violated |title=Victory for Pastor Jones; Court Rules that Pastor's Constitutional Rights Were Violated by "Peace Bond" Trial | Thomas More Law Center |publisher=Thomasmore.org |date=November 11, 2011 |accessdate=September 2, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120622215711/http://www.thomasmore.org/press-releases/2011/11/victory-pastor-jones-court-rules-pastor-s-constitutional-rights-were-violated |archivedate=June 22, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
On the evening of April 22, 2012, soon after he was interviewed at [[WJBK-TV]], Jones' gun fired accidentally as he got into his car.<ref>[http://www.freep.com/article/20110423/NEWS02/104230442/Pastor-accidentally-fires-gun-outside-TV-studio Pastor accidentally fires gun outside TV studio|Detroit Free Press]. freep.com (April 23, 2011). Retrieved April 30, 2011.</ref>
The city allowed him to protest on April 29, a week after the trial, in a designated "free speech zone" outside Dearborn City Hall.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1382322/Koran-burning-pastor-Terry-Jones-cuts-short-rally-hurled-shoes.html?ito=feeds-newsxml |location=London |work=Daily Mail |title=Koran-burning pastor Terry Jones cuts short rally after Muslim protesters pelt him with shoes |date=May 1, 2011}}</ref> Muslim protesters lined Michigan Avenue across the street from City Hall. About an hour into the protest, the crowds broke the barricades and a police line. They rushed the street but were quickly contained by riot police crews. The crowd was throwing water bottles and shoes at supporters of Jones. Police worked to push the crowd back across Michigan Avenue. At least one arrest was made.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.clickondetroit.com/news/Crowds-Bust-Barricades-At-Pastor-s-Speech-In-Dearborn/-/1719418/1793202/-/tmpgi0z/-/index.html |title=Crowds Bust Barricades At Pastor's Speech In Dearborn | News - Home |publisher=Clickondetroit.com |accessdate=September 2, 2013}}</ref>
==2010 threat to burn a Quran== In 2010 Jones announced plans to burn the [[Quran]] on the ninth anniversary of the [[September 11, 2001 attacks]], which he dubbed "International Burn a Quran Day". A wide range of politicians and religious groups strongly condemned the planned [[Quran desecration]] event. Jones said he canceled the event and intended to go to New York to meet with the [[imam]] of [[Park51]], [[Feisal Abdul Rauf]].<ref name="yahoocancel">{{Cite news |url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20100909/ap_on_re_us/quran_burning |title=Pastor nixes Quran-burning, claims NYC mosque deal |last=Gonzalez |first=Antonio |date=September 9, 2010 |work=[[Yahoo!]] |agency=Associated Press |accessdate=September 10, 2010 |location=Gainesville, Fla.}}</ref> After saying he would never burn the scriptures,<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2010/US/09/11/new.york.jones/index.html?hpt=T1#fbid=IcyXM-ln_iY&wom=false|title=Florida pastor calls off Quran burning |date=September 11, 2010 |publisher=CNN |accessdate=September 11, 2010}}</ref> on March 20, 2011, Jones oversaw the burning of a Quran.
This prompted protests, including [[2011 Mazar-i-Sharif attack|an attack in Afghanistan]] that resulted in the deaths of at least 14 people.<ref>{{cite news |title=Afghans kill 12 in protest over Quran-burning |last1=Najafizada |first1=Enayat |last2=Nordland |first2=Rod |url=http://www.boston.com/news/world/asia/articles/2011/04/02/afghans_kill_12_in_protest_over_koran_burning/ |accessdate=April 2, 2011 |newspaper=Boston Globe |date=April 2, 2011}}</ref> In April 2011, Jones claimed he is considering a trial of the Prophet Muhammad for "crimes against humanity."<ref>[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/04/06/terry-jones-mohammed-trial_n_845788.html?icid=maing-grid7%7Cmain5%7Cdl11%7Csec1_lnk2%7C54648 Pastor Terry Jones Plans To Hold Trial Of Islam Prophet Mohammed]. Huffingtonpost.com. Retrieved April 30, 2011.</ref>
===Background=== [[Dove World Outreach Center]], where the Quran burning was to occur, is a small congregation in Gainesville, with approximately 50 members. The church, led by pastor Terry Jones and his wife, Sylvia, first gained media attention in the late 2000s (decade) for its [[Islamophobia|anti-Islamic]] and [[Homophobia|anti-homosexual]] messages. In 2009, Dove World posted a sign on its lawn which stated in large red letters "Islam is of the Devil".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gainesville.com/article/20090708/ARTICLES/907081008 |title=Anti-Islam church sign stirs up community outrage |author1=Lise Fisher |author2=Karen Voyles |publisher=Gainesville.com |date = July 8, 2009}}</ref> Several members of the church also sent their children to their first day of school in August 2009 wearing t-shirts with "Islam is of the Devil" printed on the back.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gainesville.com/article/20090826/ARTICLES/908261007 |title='Devil' shirts send kids home |author=Christopher Curry |publisher=Gainesville.com |date=August 26, 2009}}</ref>
The proposal to burn Qurans began with a series of Twitter messages on July 12,<ref name=WPO910>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/09/10/AR2010091007428.html |title=Pastor Terry Jones's Quran-burning threat started with a tweet |author1=Ann Gerhart |author2=Ernesto Londoño |publisher=Washington Post |date=September 10, 2010 |accessdate=October 16, 2010}}</ref> and a related discussion on the now-removed [[Facebook]] group "Islam is of the Devil", named after Terry Jones's book. Jones invited Christians to burn the Muslim holy book to remember all 9/11 victims. It was to be held from 6 p.m. to 9 p.m.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.cnn.com/2010-07-29/us/florida.burn.quran.day_1_american-muslims-religion-cair-spokesman-ibrahim-hooper?_s=PM |title=Church plans Quran-burning event |date=July 30, 2010 |author=Lauren Russell |publisher=US CNN News |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120716131328/http://articles.cnn.com/2010-07-29/us/florida.burn.quran.day_1_quran-burning-florida-church-terry-jones-american-muslims-religion?_s=PM:US |archivedate=July 16, 2012 |accessdate=September 20, 2016 |df=mdy }}</ref> The idea initially had little support and considerable opposition, but [[Religion News Service]] ran a story describing Jones's claim that he had received Qurans to burn. [[Council on American-Islamic Relations|CAIR]] refused to respond, but other religious organizations did. On July 25 Jones posted a YouTube video in which he held up a Quran and said "This is the book that is responsible for 9/11. No, to me it looks like the religion of the devil" which garnered substantial media attention. On August 3, Gainesville mayor [[Craig Lowe]] asked the world's media to ignore Jones's church as a "tiny fringe group and an embarrassment to our community", but coverage continued to increase.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.theage.com.au/world/how-the-media-ignited-koran-burning-story-20100911-155yf.html |title=How the media ignited Quran burning story |date=September 12, 2010 |publisher=The Age (from Guardian?) |location=Melbourne |first=Matthew |last=Weaver}}</ref> In early August, [[Sunni]] scholars at [[al-Azhar University]] in [[Cairo]] issued a statement warning of "dangerous consequences" if Qurans were burned.<ref name=WPO910 /> U.S. President Obama condemned the plan saying it would endanger the lives of U.S. troops abroad.<ref name=WPO910 /> American Muslims responded by saying they would celebrate September 11, 2010 as 'love Jesus day' emphasizing the fact that Jesus is believed to be a messenger of God in Islam. Other groups asked people to celebrate Read the Quran day as a means to international understanding.
===Reactions===
====Local (Florida) ==== A Gainesville Interfaith Forum which was established in November 2009 in response to earlier [[Islamophobia|anti-Islam]] activities of the church requested for the declaration of September 11 as "Interfaith Solidarity Day", a request that was honored by mayor [[Craig Lowe]].<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.gainesville.com/article/20100811/ARTICLES/100819861/1105/NEWS?Title=Local-leaders-forming-response-to-Quran-burning|title = Local leaders forming response to Quran burning|author = Chad Smith|publisher = Gainesville.com|date = August 11, 2010}}</ref> The Forum scheduled a "Gathering for Peace, Understanding and Hope" at Trinity United Methodist Church on the day before the planned burning.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://religion.blogs.cnn.com/2010/08/20/religious-leaders-speak-out-against-international-burn-a-quran-day/?hpt=T2 |title=Religious leaders speak out against International Burn a Quran Day|work=CNN Belief Blog|publisher=CNN.com |date=August 20, 2010 |accessdate=September 8, 2010}}</ref> Mayor Lowe referred to Dove World as a "tiny fringe group and an embarrassment to our community".<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.gainesville.com/article/20100804/ARTICLES/8041009|title = Mayor Lowe: Dove World is 'an embarrassment'|author = Chad Smith|publisher = Gainesville Sun|date = August 4, 2010}}</ref> 20 local religious leaders gathered Thursday, September 2, 2010, to call for citizens to rally around Muslims "in a time when so much venom is directed toward them."<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.gainesville.com/article/20100902/ARTICLES/100909904|title = Religious leaders call for solidarity against Quran burning|author = Chad Smith|publisher = Gainesville Sun|date = September 2, 2010}}</ref>
====National==== [[File:Protest against US Church.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Protest against International Burn a Quran Day held in [[Delhi]], [[India]].]]
Shortly after the event was announced the [[National Association of Evangelicals]] recommended that the event be canceled.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.nae.net/news-and-events/469-press-release-nae-urges-cancellation-of-planned-quran-burning|title = Press Release: NAE Urges Cancellation of Planned Qu'ran Burning|publisher = National Association of Evangelicals|date = July 29, 2010|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5sahSpH2O?url=http://www.nae.net/news-and-events/469-press-release-nae-urges-cancellation-of-planned-quran-burning|archivedate = September 8, 2010|df = mdy-all}}</ref> The Southern Baptist convention also spoke out against it <ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Global-Issues/2010/0909/11-countries-speaking-out-against-Koran-burning-in-Florida/Vatican-City|title = 11 countries speaking out against Quran burning in Florida|publisher = Christian Science Monitor|date = September 9, 2010}}</ref> The [[World Evangelical Alliance]] "asks Muslim neighbors to recognize that the plans announced by a Florida group to burn copies of the Quran on September 11 do not represent the vast majority of Christians." "It dishonors the memory of those who died in the 9/11 attacks and further perpetuates unacceptable violence." The event is broadly condemned by American religious leaders.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.worldevangelicals.org/news/article.htm?id=3074&cat=main|title=The Gospel of Jesus Christ is Good News; Burning the Qu'ran is Bad News|date=September 8, 2010|publisher=WEA – [[World Evangelical Alliance]]|accessdate=September 10, 2010}}</ref>
John Rankin, President of the Theological Education Institute in Connecticut, has started a "Yes to the Bible, No to the Burning of the Quran" effort. Also Jennifer Bryson is advocating Christian intra-faith dialogue and Christian rejection of "Burn a Quran Day".<ref>{{Cite news|author= Bryson, Jennifer |title= Christians Must Reject "Burn a Quran Day" |url=http://newsweek.washingtonpost.com/onfaith/guestvoices/2010/08/christians_must_reject_burn_a_quran_day.html |work= [[Washington Post]] |date= August 27, 2010 |accessdate= August 27, 2010}}</ref>
Feisal Abdul Rauf, the cleric behind the move to build a Muslim community centre near "Ground Zero" ([[Park51]]) said that, should the burning of Qurans have gone ahead,
</blockquote>it would have created a disaster in the Muslim world. It would have strengthened the radicals. It would have enhanced the possibility of terrorist acts against America and American interests.</blockquote>
He also added that retracting the decision to build the mosque would send a wrong message that "moving it is that the headline in the Muslim world will be Islam is under attack in America."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.almanar.com.lb/newssite/NewsDetails.aspx?id=153744&language=en |publisher=Al-Manar TV |title=NY Imam: Quran Burning would Have Been A Disaster |date=September 12, 2010 |accessdate=September 13, 2010 }}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
A group of American veterans of the [[War in Iraq]] and the [[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|War in Afghanistan]] wrote an [[open letter]] to the ''[[Huffington Post]]'' calling on the American public to respect "the values we risked our lives to protect". "When citizens here participate in hateful rhetoric and intolerance toward Muslims, it leaves soldiers over there exposed." The letter concludes by asking "America, you gotta have our back."<ref>{{cite news |title=Iraq, Afghan Veterans Call For Respect For Muslims: 'America, You Gotta Have Our Back' |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/09/13/veterans-muslims-respect-iraq-afghanistan_n_714646.html |accessdate=March 29, 2011 |newspaper=Huffington Post |date=September 13, 2010 |first=Jeff |last=Muskus}}</ref>
[[U.S. Secretary of State]] [[Hillary Clinton]] said, "It's regrettable that a pastor in Gainesville, Florida with a church of no more than fifty people can make this outrageous and distressful, disgraceful plan and get, you know, the world's attention." She also said, "It doesn't in any way represent America or Americans or American government or American religious or political leadership," and she emphasized the hope of the [[U.S. Government]] that the church would not go through with their plans.<ref>{{Cite news |author=Madison, Lucy |title=Hillary Clinton, Joe Lieberman Denounce Florida Pastor's Planned Quran Burning Event |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-503544_162-20015869-503544.html |publisher=[[CBS News]] |date=September 8, 2010}}</ref> [[US Secretary of Defense]] [[Robert Gates]] called Pastor Jones asking him not to go through with his Quran burning.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-503544_162-20016023-503544.html |title=Robert Gates Urged Terry Jones to Call Off Quran Burning – Political Hotsheet |last=Delargy |first=Christine |date=September 9, 2010 |publisher=CBS News}}</ref> The US embassy in Kabul issued a statement condemning the plans.<ref name="bbc2010-11-07"/> [[Robert Gibbs]], [[White House Press Secretary]], criticized the plans stating "any type of activity like that that puts our troops in harm's way would be a concern to this administration".<ref name="bbc2010-11-07"/>
The commander of the [[International Security Assistance Force]] in [[Afghanistan]], General [[David Petraeus]] said, "It is precisely the kind of action the Taliban uses and could cause significant problems. Not just here, but everywhere in the world we are engaged with the Islamic community." On the same day hundreds of Afghans protested in [[Kabul]] against the planned Quran burning event, chanting "[[death to America]]" and throwing rocks at a passing military convoy. Military officials also expressed fears that the protests would spread to other cities. Military officers at [[the Pentagon]] consequently said they hoped the rare incursion into politics by a military commander would convince Pastor Jones to cancel his plans. The pastor responded to Petraeus' statement that, "We understand the General's concerns. We are sure that his concerns are legitimate. [Nonetheless] [w]e must send a clear message to the radical element of Islam. We will no longer be controlled and dominated by their fears and threats."<ref>{{Cite news|author1=Barnes, Julian E. |author2=Rosenberg, Matthew |author3=Fields, Gary |title= Petraeus Condemns U.S. Church's Plan to Burn Qurans |url= https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703713504575475500753093116 |work= [[Wall Street Journal]] |date= September 7, 2010 |accessdate= September 6, 2010}}</ref>
[[Republican Party (United States)|Republicans]] in Congress also criticized Jones and his plans. "Just because you have a right to do something in America does not mean it is the right thing to do," said U.S. [[House Minority Leader]] [[John Boehner]].<ref>{{Cite news|author= Kevin Derby|title= World Weighs In to Condemn Terry Jones' Planned Quran-Burning|url= http://www.sunshinestatenews.com/story/world-weighs-in-condemn-terry-jones-planned-quran-burning|work= Sunshine News|date= September 8, 2010 |accessdate= September 13, 2010}}</ref> Former Alaska governor [[Sarah Palin]] also criticized Jones, calling his plans "insensitive and an unnecessary provocation",<ref>{{Cite news|author= Bruno Waterfield|title= 9/11 Quran burning: Sarah Palin calls it 'unnecessary provocation'|url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/usa/7990783/911-Koran-burning-Sarah-Palin-calls-it-unnecessary-provocation.html|work= [[The Daily Telegraph]]|date= September 9, 2010 |accessdate= September 16, 2010|location=London}}</ref> and Republican 2008 presidential nominee John McCain and [[Senate Minority Leader]] Mitch McConnell both argued that the actions of Jones put American troops overseas at risk.<ref>{{Cite news|title= McCain, McConnell plead against Quran burning|url= https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jDdtqH9bACmBUlS46PXVXrVZm3Jw|work= [[The Daily Telegraph]]|date= September 9, 2010 |accessdate= September 16, 2010}}</ref> President Obama made a statement on ABC News regarding this event, stating that "what he is purposing to do is completely contrary to our values as Americans." He added that Terry Jones's plan to burn the Quran will put American soldiers at risk.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Obama on ABC News|url= https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7igP-XwnDbo}}</ref> [[David Wood (Christian apologist)|David Wood]] disagreed with pastor Terry Jones attempts in the [[2010 Quran-burning controversy|Quran burning]], and compared it to the [[Uthman ibn Affan#Koran|Uthman Quran]] burning.<ref>[http://www.cnsnews.com/news/article/72415 Original Quran-Burning Took Place in the Mid-Seventh Century] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100919063531/http://www.cnsnews.com/news/article/72415 |date=September 19, 2010 }} CNS News [[Cybercast News Service]]</ref> One book distribution website, SacredBookSource.com, offered to give away 1,001 free Qurans and 1,000 free Bibles for every Quran Jones destroyed.<ref>[http://www.sacredbooksource.com Sacred Book Source website] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120323104706/http://www.sacredbooksource.com/ |date=March 23, 2012 }}</ref>
====International==== The [[Evangelische Allianz#Germany|German Evangelical Alliance]] formally dissociated itself from the proposed Quran burning, because of the widely circulated report that in his time in [[Cologne]], Jones had been associated with the evangelical alliance.<ref name="German Evangelical"/><ref name="Sekte">{{cite web|url=http://pro-medienmagazin.de/gesellschaft.html?&news%5Baction%5D=detail&news%5Bid%5D=3215|title=Terry Jones ist kein Evangelikaler|publisher=Christlicher Medienverbund KEP|date=September 8, 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5sbyzN84A?url=http://pro-medienmagazin.de/gesellschaft.html?&news%5baction%5d=detail&news%5bid%5d=3215=detail&news%5bid%5d=3215#|archivedate=September 9, 2010|language=German|deadurl=yes|df=mdy-all|access-date=September 9, 2010}}</ref>
The ''Al-Falluja'' web forum threatened a bloody war against America in response to the burning of the Quran.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/us/Florida-church-plans-to-burn-Quran-on-9/11-anniversary/articleshow/6242137.cms |title=Florida church plans to burn Quran on 9/11 anniversary |work=[[Indiatimes]] |date=August 1, 2010 |location=Miami |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100803204743/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/us/Florida-church-plans-to-burn-Quran-on-9/11-anniversary/articleshow/6242137.cms |archivedate=August 3, 2010 }}</ref>
Various other Muslims, such as the [[Ahmadiyya Muslim Community]] have argued that the Dove World Outreach Center is not following the true teachings of Christianity of tolerance and love.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alislam.org/topics/reply/Love-for-All-Pamphlet.pdf|title=A Peaceful Message to the World|accessdate=September 7, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://neighbornewspapers.com/stories/Dove-Church-Plans-to-Burn-Quran-Ahmadi-Muslims-Protest,162870?content_source=&category_id=6&search_filter=&event_mode=&event_ts_from=&list_type=&order_by=&order_sort=&content_class=&sub_type=&town_id=&page= |title=Dove Church Plans to Burn Quran: Ahmadi-Muslims Protest |date=August 29, 2010 |accessdate=September 7, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304065930/http://neighbornewspapers.com/stories/Dove-Church-Plans-to-Burn-Quran-Ahmadi-Muslims-Protest,162870?content_source=&category_id=6&search_filter=&event_mode=&event_ts_from=&list_type=&order_by=&order_sort=&content_class=&sub_type=&town_id=&page= |archivedate=March 4, 2016 }}</ref> They quote [[Jesus]]: "But I say unto you, Love your enemies, bless them that curse you, do good to them that hate you, and pray for them which despitefully use you, and persecute you..."([[Gospel of Matthew]] 5:44–45). The Head of the Community, [[Mirza Masroor Ahmad]], has stated that "Religious extremism, be it Christian extremism, Muslim extremism or any other kind, is never a true reflection of the religion".<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-11264159 |title=Koran-burning plan condemned at London mosque |publisher=BBC News |date=September 10, 2010 |accessdate=September 11, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://pr-usa.net/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=477845&Itemid=30 |title=UK MUSLIMS SHOCKED BY PLAN TO BURN HOLY QURAN IN USA |accessdate=September 7, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717191249/http://pr-usa.net/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=477845&Itemid=30 |archivedate=July 17, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
On August 27, approximately 100 people protested in Indonesia outside the U.S. Embassy. Roni Ruslan of [[Hizbut Tahrir]], which advocates Islamic law, said,
<blockquote>No one will be able to control this reaction.... We urge the U.S. government and Christian leaders to stop the crazy plan from this small sect. It's an insult to Islam and to 1.5 billion Muslims around the world.<ref name=FOX827>{{cite news |url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2010/08/27/international-protests-begin-ahead-sept-koran-burning-event-florida/ |title=International Protests Begin Ahead of Sept. 11 Quran Burning Event in Florida |publisher=FoxNews.com |date=August 27, 2010}}</ref></blockquote>
On September 4, thousands of Indonesians, mostly Muslims, took part in events across the country organized by Hizbut Tahrir. Rokhmat Labib, chairman of the group, called the planned [[book burning]] a provocation and predicted that Muslims would fight back should it take place. Lahib said that Muslims must not stay silent when their faith is threatened.<ref>{{Cite news |author=Schonhardt, Sara |title=Indonesian Muslims Protest Plans to Burn Quran on September 11 |url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/Indonesian-Muslims-Protest-Plans-to-Burn-Koran-on-September-11-102250384.html |work=[[Voice of America News]] |date=September 5, 2010 |accessdate=September 7, 2010}}</ref>
The [[World Evangelical Alliance]] condemned the plans to burn the Quran.<ref name="WEA2">{{cite web|url=http://www.worldevangelicals.org/news/article.htm?id=3077&cat=press|title=Secretary General of the World Evangelical Alliance condemns burning of Qur'an|author=Geoff Tunnicliffe|publisher=World Evangelical Alliance|date=September 9, 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5scLutX0F?url=http://www.worldevangelicals.org/news/article.htm?id=3077&cat=press|archivedate=September 9, 2010|quote=The WEA, on behalf of its member churches, Christian organisations and bodies, strongly condemns the Dove World Outreach Center's plans to burn copies of the Qur'an.|deadurl=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
[[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] issued a statement declaring that "A key tenet of our faith is to accord everyone the freedom to worship as they choose. It is regrettable that anyone would regard the burning of any scriptural text as a legitimate form of protest or disagreement."<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://newsroom.lds.org/ldsnewsroom/eng/news-releases-stories/church-statement-on-the-burning-of-the-koran |title=Church Statement on the Burning of the Quran |date=September 8, 2010}}</ref>
The [[International Humanist and Ethical Union]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iheu.org/world-union-humanists-and-atheists-condemn-quran-burning|title=World union of Humanists and Atheists condemn Quran burning|date=August 19, 2010|publisher=IHEU}}<!-- - 09:09--></ref> was also critical of the plans to burn the Quran.
On Friday, September 10 in the northern Afghan city of [[Fayzabad]], thousands took part in a protest against the planned Quran-burning following [[Eid ul-Fitr]] prayers. Violent demonstrators threw stones at a German-controlled [[NATO]] base. Initial reports said troops inside opened fire, killing up to three people and injuring several others, but a local police official said that only local police, not the NATO troops, were involved in the shooting.<ref name="CBS News">{{Cite news|author= Reals, Tucker |title= Afghans Attack NATO Base in Quran Burning Protest |url= http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-503543_162-20016041-503543.html |publisher= [[CBS News]] |date=September 10, 2010 |accessdate=September 20, 2016}}</ref><ref name="AsianAge">{{Cite news|title=1 dies in Afghan protest over Quran burning |url=http://www.asianage.com/international/1-dies-afghan-protest-over-quran-burning-277 |work=[[The Asian Age]] |date=September 10, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928071827/http://www.asianage.com/international/1-dies-afghan-protest-over-quran-burning-277 |archivedate=September 28, 2011 |accessdate=September 20, 2016 |df=mdy }}</ref> According to the acting police chief of [[Badakshan]] the protesters broke down the first perimeter gate surrounding the base and beat Afghan security guards and police on duty with sticks. Before opening fire police allegedly fired warning shots and were also fired upon from the direction of the demonstrators, said the police official.<ref name="CBS News"/> A local police chief talking to the BBC gave his estimates of the number of protesters to around 1,500 but said that the incident that led to the shooting was a separate one with 150 people participating. This official also said that private security guards were the ones who fired at the people who tried to force their way inside the base.<ref name="BBC10">{{Cite news |title=Protests against US Quran-burning sweep Afghanistan |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-south-asia-11258739 |work=[[BBC News]] |date=September 10, 2010 |accessdate=September 10, 2010}}</ref> NATO has launched an investigation into the incident.<ref name="JPost">{{Cite news |title= 1 killed in Afghan protest against Quran burning |url=http://www.jpost.com/International/Article.aspx?id=187683 |work=[[The Jerusalem Post]] |agency=[[Associated Press|AP]] |date=September 10, 2010 |accessdate=September 10, 2010}}</ref> General Zahir Khan of the Kabul police described Quran-burning a thinly disguised pretext for anti-government rallies with the [[Taliban]] in attendance.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/la-fg-afghan-protest-20100916,0,5439594.story?track=rss|title=Dozens injured in Kabul protest over Quran-burning threat|author=Laura King|publisher=Chicago Tribune}}</ref>
Protest rallies were held in several other Afghan provinces: [[Nimruz Province|Nimruz]], [[Kunar Province|Kunar]], [[Nangarhar Province|Nangarhar]], [[Parwan Province|Parwan]], [[Baghlan Province|Baghlan]], [[Kunduz Province|Kunduz]], [[Balkh Province|Balkh]] and [[Farah Province|Farah]]. The Afghan President [[Hamid Karzai]] also spoke out against the burning of Qurans saying, "By burning the Quran, they cannot harm it. The Quran is in the hearts and minds of one-and-a-half billion people. Insulting the Quran is an insult to nations."<ref name="BBC10"/> Protests continued throughout the next two days, with three protesters wounded on September 11 and four on September 12 as Afghan security forces shot into groups of protesters, some armed with sticks or throwing stones, to disperse them.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://au.news.yahoo.com/a/-/world/7928883/afghans-protest-again-as-koran-tensions-simmer/|title=Afghans protest again as Quran tensions simmer|author=Paul Tait|publisher=Reuters|date=September 12, 2010}}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Two died in hospital due to severe gunshot wounds.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://uk.news.yahoo.com/22/20100912/tpl-uk-afghanistan-protests-81f3b62.html|title=Two Afghans killed during Quran-burning protests|author=Hamid Shalizi|publisher=Reuters|date=September 12, 2010}}</ref> On September 11, protests continued in the country, when Afghan security forces fought back thousands of demonstrators. Four demonstrators were wounded by security forces; firing when they tried to storm several government buildings in [[Pul-e-Alam]], in [[Logar province]]. They also hurled stones at such buildings as the department for women's affairs. In Badakhshan province, another thousand people protested three separate districts, though the police chief said it was peaceful.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.almanar.com.lb/newssite/NewsDetails.aspx?id=153682&language=en |publisher=Al-Manar TV |title=Afghans Protest Holy Quran Burning Plot for Second Day |date=September 11, 2010 |accessdate=September 13, 2010 }}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
The prominent [[Qatar]] based scholar, [[Yusuf al-Qaradawi]] despite condemning the desecration said,
<blockquote>Responding to an assault is not by carrying out another assault, as this is discouraged in Islam .... Moreover, we, as Muslims, are required to show respect to and believe in the divinely-revealed books and all preceding prophets. If a person insults Jesus (peace be upon him), I, as a Muslim, should feel annoyed by this and act in his defense. This is what happened upon the release of a film which attacked Jesus: Muslims living in the country where the film was shown reacted angrily in protest. We believe in and highly respect all prophets and messengers, including Moses and Jesus (peace be upon them all).... The noble Quran even goes further and forbids us from cursing the pagans' idols, saying: (And do not abuse those whom they call upon besides Allah, lest exceeding the limits they should abuse Allah out of ignorance.) (Al-An`am 6:108).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.onislam.net/english/shariah/contemporary-issues/interviews-reviews-and-events/449388-sheikh-qaradawis-first-interview-with-onislamnet.html|title=Sheikh Qaradawi's First Interview with Onislam.net}}</ref></blockquote>
Small rallies were reported in Pakistan in [[Karachi]] and the central Pakistani city [[Multan]] with around 200 protesters.<ref name="BBC10"/> There were also protests in Indonesia, Gaza, and [[Demographics of India|India]], a non-Muslim majority country.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/asia/2010/09/2010910144912849393.html |title=Quran burning threat fuels protests |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=September 10, 2010 |accessdate=September 13, 2010}}</ref> On September 15, regarding reports that at least 20 deaths worldwide were connected to Quran desecration protests, Randall Terry responded that "Such logic is like saying that a woman who is abused by her boyfriend or husband is guilty of bringing violence on herself because she said or did something that irritated him."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/usnw/20100915/pl_usnw/DC65672_1 |title=Mr. Terry Responds to Deaths Over Quran Burning |date=September 15, 2010 |publisher=UPI}}</ref>
Protests in [[Kashmir]] escalated over several days, as Quran demonstrations quickly turned into separatist protests against the Indian government in the Muslim-majority province. On September 13, protesters defied a military-imposed curfew, setting fire to a Christian missionary school and government buildings. At least 13 people were shot dead by police, and one policeman was killed by a thrown rock; at least 113 policemen and 45 protesters were wounded.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/article.asp?edition_id=10&categ_id=2&article_id=119238|title=Thirteen killed in Indian Kashmir as Quran desecration protests continue |date=September 14, 2010 |author=Reuters/AFP |publisher=The Daily Star}}</ref><ref>[http://english.aljazeera.net/news/asia/2010/09/201091312934825752.html Violence flares in Indian Kashmir], Aljazeera, September 13, 2010</ref> On September 12, a church was burned and a curfew instituted in [[Punjab (Indian state)|Punjab]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/After-Quran-rumour-Punjab-church-gutted/articleshow/6550154.cms |title=After Quran rumour, Punjab church gutted |date=September 14, 2010 |publisher=Times of India}}</ref> Violence also spread into [[Poonch]] in the [[Jammu]] division, with three protesters shot by police. Protesters burned several government offices and vehicles.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://hindu.com/2010/09/16/stories/2010091665151200.htm |title=3 killed as violence spreads to Poonch |author=Shujaat Bukhari |publisher=The Hindu |date=September 16, 2010 |location=Chennai, India}}</ref> Police prevented the burning of a Christian school in Poonch, and another in Mendhar the next day, in clashes leaving four protesters killed, 19 wounded, but dozens of government offices, a police station, and eight vehicles were burned.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.asianews.it/news-en/Kashmir:-Muslims-try-to-burn-a-Christian-school-%28only-in-name%29-19476.html |title=Kashmir: Muslims try to burn a Christian school (only in name) |author=Shefali Prabhu |date=September 16, 2010 |publisher=Asianews.it}}</ref> As of September 16, the [[Hindustan Times]] placed the death toll at 90, blaming much of the resentment on the indefinite military curfew, the first in ten years to affect the entire Kashmir Valley.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/rssfeed/chunk-ht-ui-indiasectionpage-north/Kashmiris-locked-up-hurt-humiliated-by-curfew/Article1-600653.aspx |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130125112214/http://www.hindustantimes.com/rssfeed/chunk-ht-ui-indiasectionpage-north/Kashmiris-locked-up-hurt-humiliated-by-curfew/Article1-600653.aspx |dead-url=yes |archive-date=January 25, 2013 |title=Kashmiris locked up, hurt, humiliated by curfew |author=Toufiq Rashid |date=September 16, 2010 |publisher=Hindustan Times }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/rssfeed/jandk/Fourth-day-of-indefinite-curfew-in-Kashmir-toll-90/Article1-600793.aspx|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120903173436/http://www.hindustantimes.com/rssfeed/jandk/Fourth-day-of-indefinite-curfew-in-Kashmir-toll-90/Article1-600793.aspx|dead-url=yes|archive-date=September 3, 2012|title=Fourth day of indefinite curfew in Kashmir, toll 90|author=Indo-Asian News Service|publisher=Hindustan Times|date=September 16, 2010}}</ref>
In Somalia, the [[al-Qaida]]-inspired group [[Al-Shabaab (militant group)|Al-Shabaab]] organized a protest rally against the Quran-burning attended by thousands.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/article.asp?edition_id=10&categ_id=2&article_id=119315#axzz0zeKtMbMr|title=Somalia's Al-Shabaab rally over Quran burning|author=Agence France Presse (AFP)|publisher=The Daily Star|date=September 16, 2010}}</ref>
The head of Iran's Islamic Culture and Relations Organization labeled the Quran burning proposal a "Zionist" insult.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.presstv.ir/detail.aspx?id=138498&sectionid=351020101|title = 'Burn a Quran Day, a Zionist outlook'|publisher = [[Press TV]]|date = August 13, 2010}}</ref> A group of Iranian students also protested outside the Swiss embassy in Tehran to protest the desecration of the Quran, and chanted slogans condemned the desecration on the anniversary of the 9/11 attacks.<ref name="presstv"/> The Iranian ''House of Cartoon'' invited international artists to an online exhibition to condemn the desecration of the Qurans on the theme of ''Devil against Holy Books'', ''Devil against Human Nature'' and ''Terry Jones''. More than 30 cartoons had been submitted from Iran, Turkey, Brazil, Ukraine and other countries since the event was announced on September 13. While there would be no prizes, the entries would be published at a later date.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/142706.html |title=PressTV – Cartoonists slam Quran desecration |publisher=Presstv.ir |accessdate=October 2, 2010}}</ref> Foreign Minister [[Manouchehr Mottaki]] called the proposal "heinous" at a joint press conference with his Malawian counterpart [[Etta Banda]]. He also added that "The stance of the Muslim world, including the Islamic Republic of Iran, is transparent: Condemnation of this heinous, insulting and sacrilegious act by whomever perpetuated it. We clearly see the hands of the Zionists behind all threats and provocative moves [aimed to strain relations] between the believers of various faiths. This is exactly the sort of extremist move that seeks to realize their objectives through creating religious discord."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.almanar.com.lb/newssite/NewsDetails.aspx?id=153802&language=en |title=Iran Condemns The Holy Quran Burning as A "Heinous" Desecration 13/09/2010 |publisher=Al-Manar TV |date=September 13, 2010 |accessdate=September 13, 2010 }}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
Iran's ambassador to the United Nations, Mohammad Khazaee, said he had filed a complaint with the body to "attract the international community's attention to Iran's stance and to warn against the serious repercussions of insulting the holy book of Muslims and hurting the religious feelings of more than one-fourth of the world's population." He also condemned the actions as "abhorrent."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/142702.html |title=PressTV – Leader Quran message filed at UN |publisher=Presstv.ir |accessdate=October 2, 2010}}</ref> Iran's parliament speaker [[Ali Larijani]] censured the US for its apparent silence on the "outrageous act of desecrating the holy Quran, urging the Muslim world to take swift action against it." He added that the "silence of those who beat the drums for freedom and democracy on the blasphemous decision has drawn the ire of freedom-seeking humans and stirred international hatred of the US." He also said the desecration of the Quran would be a "brutal" act that shows "barbarism in the modern era." While he concluded that such measures would "undoubtedly hurt spiritual and religious feelings of millions of Muslims across the world as well as followers of all divine faiths," and warned American legislators they should expect a "harsh fate" if they do not act "wisely."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/142296.html |title=Iran slams silence on Quran desecration |publisher=Press TV |accessdate=September 13, 2010}}</ref> The parliament's Presiding Board member, Mohammad Dehqan, said that "Whenever Zionists want to cover up their atrocities in Palestine, they try to trigger anti-Islamic sentiments across the United States and the West to deflect global public attention from their brutalities against Palestinians." He also criticised the "Zionists" for trying to paint a violent picture of Islam to discourage others from converting to Islam; he went on to urge Muslims around the world to "remain united to stop the recurrence of similar profane moves."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/142281.html |title='Zionists behind Quran burning plan' |publisher=Press TV |accessdate=September 13, 2010}}</ref> The head of the National Security and Foreign Policy Commission of parliament, Alaeddin Boroujerdi, said the "US police reluctance to react to such sacrilegious action indicates Washington's green light to such a heinous crime. The US government should take serious action against the perpetrators of this provocative move and declare its stance on that regard."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/142437.html |title=PressTV – 'US accountable for Quran desecration' |publisher=Presstv.ir |date=September 14, 2010 |accessdate=October 2, 2010}}</ref> [[Grand Ayatollah]]s [[Hossein Noori Hamedani]] and [[Naser Makarem Shirazi]] favored the killing of Quran-burners, but that the permission of a religious judge was required.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/afp/20100913/wl_mideast_afp/usattacks9yearsreligionislamdemosiran_20100913155436 |title=Iran clerics vow death for Koran-defilers |date=September 13, 2010 |publisher=UPI}}</ref>
In Iraq, Grand Ayatollah [[Ali al-Sistani]] cautioned people to show restraint labeling the act "expression of hatred of Islam."<ref name="BBC10"/>
====Counter protests==== A hacker with nickname "Iraq Resistance" posted a voice-altered video to YouTube published under the byname "iqziad", claiming to have released the "Here you have" worm to "demand respect for Islam", blaming Terry Jones, and saying "I can smash all of those infected, but I wouldn't". The worm, first discovered August 20, attacked organizations including [[NASA]], [[Walt Disney]], and the [[Florida Department of Transportation]], and produced spam that rose to 10% of all email traffic on September 9.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eweek.com/c/a/Security/YouTube-Video-Claims-Here-You-Have-Worm-Targeted-US-194217/ |title=YouTube Video Claims Here You Have Worm Targeted U.S. |author=Brian Prince |date=September 13, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eweek.com/c/a/Security/Here-You-Have-Worm-Floods-Email-Inboxes-184515/|title='Here You Have' Worm Floods E-Mail Inboxes|author=Brian Prince|date=September 9, 2010|publisher=eWeek}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.symantec.com/security_response/writeup.jsp?docid=2010-082013-3322-99&tabid=2|title=W32.Imsolk.A@mm|date=August 20, 2010|publisher=Symantec}}</ref>
In South Africa, on September 10, Johannesburg businessman Mohammed Vawda had announced his own intention to burn the Bible on September 11 in the [[Central Business District (Johannesburg)|Johannesburg CBD]] in response to DWOC's own announcement.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.newstime.co.za/SouthAfrica/Jo%E2%80%99Burg_Man_Plans_Bible_Burning/10869/|title = Jo'Burg Man Plans Bible Burning|publisher = NewsTime.co.za|date = September 10, 2010|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100914065504/http://www.newstime.co.za/SouthAfrica/Jo%E2%80%99Burg_Man_Plans_Bible_Burning/10869|archivedate = September 14, 2010|df = mdy-all}}</ref> However, an Islamic lawyers' association, Scholars of the Truth, quickly intervened by filing an injunction against Vawda in court on the basis of opposition against burning any religious texts,<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.timeslive.co.za/local/article652439.ece/Court-bid-to-stop-Jozi-Bible-burning|title = Court bid to stop Jozi Bible burning|author = SAPA|author-link = South African Press Association|publisher = [[The Sunday Times (South Africa)|Times LIVE]]|date = September 10, 2010<!-- 11:54 AM-->}}</ref> and Judge Sita Kolbe of the [[South Gauteng High Court]] granted the injunction, thus prohibiting Vawda's announced burning.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Global-News/2010/0910/In-South-Africa-judge-outlaws-burning-Bibles-Qurans-other-holy-books|title = In South Africa, judge outlaws burning Bibles, Qurans, other holy books|author = Ian Evans|publisher = Christian Science Monitor|date = September 10, 2010}}</ref> Lawyer and Scholars of the Truth spokesperson Yasmin Omar, who spearheaded the injunction with her husband Zahir, stated that the judge's ruling established that "freedom of expression is not unlimited if one exercises freedom of expression that is harmful to others".<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3952365,00.html|title = South Africa blocks burning of Bibles|publisher = [[Ynet]]|date = September 11, 2010<!--, 09:43-->}}</ref>
====Governmental reactions==== {{flag|Canada}}. Prime Minister [[Stephen Harper]], condemned the planned Quran-burning in unequivocal terms, and said, "My God and my Christ is a tolerant God, and that's what we want to see in this world".<ref name="CBCHarper">{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/world/story/2010/09/08/florida-pastor-quran.html |title=Harper condemns Quran burning plan |publisher=CBC News |date=September 8, 2010 |accessdate=September 13, 2010}}</ref>
{{flag|Cuba}}. Former president [[Fidel Castro]] called the planned book burning "a huge media show". After Jones called off the event, Castro said, "It would be nice to know what the [[FBI]] agents who visited him said 'to persuade him.'"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.middle-east-online.com/english/?id=41259|title=Burn A Quran Day Pastor (What Should be Done About It?)|date=September 12, 2010|publisher=Middle East Online}}</ref>
{{flag|France}}. Defence minister [[Hervé Morin]] said that the threatened Quran burning and a [[French ban on full length Islamic veils]] enacted shortly afterward did not put French or NATO troops at increased risk: "when you are at the maximum, you cannot go higher".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5iHmKHX5DdYiGDy9hu4AwcpOxOeEAD9I95VQG0|title=Morin: Veil law, Quran issue don't up troop risk|agency=Associated Press|date=September 16, 2010}}{{dead link|date=April 2011}}</ref>
{{flag|Germany}}. Chancellor [[Angela Merkel]] said of the planned Florida event, "It is plainly disrespectful – even abhorrent. It's simply wrong."<ref>{{Cite news |author=Connor, Richard |title=Merkel defends 'Muhammad' cartoonist, condemns Quran-burning |url=http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,,5986351,00.html |publisher=[[Deutsche Welle]] |date=September 8, 2010}}</ref>
{{flag|Indonesia}}. President [[Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono]] warned in a televised speech that the plans to burn the Quran threatened world peace.<ref name="BBC10"/>
{{IRI}}. [[Supreme Leader of Iran]] [[Ayatollah Seyyed Ali Khamenei]] said "All Muslims hold the US government and their politicians accountable. If the US government is sincere in its claims of not having been involved in this incident, it must mete out a befitting punishment to the main perpetrators of this serious crime".<ref name="presstv">{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/142424.html |title=PressTV – Iranian students slam Quran desecration |publisher=Presstv.ir |date=September 14, 2010 |accessdate=October 2, 2010}}</ref> President [[Mahmoud Ahmadinejad]] called the plan a "Zionist plot that is against the teachings of all divine prophets."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.almanar.com.lb/newssite/NewsDetails.aspx?id=153578&language=en |title=Ahmadinejad: Quran Burning Would Fuel Israel Annihilation 10/09/2010 |publisher=Al-Manar TV |date=September 10, 2010 |accessdate=September 13, 2010 }}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
{{LBN}}. President [[Michel Suleiman]] denounced the plans adding that burning the Quran is a clear contradiction of the teachings of the three Abrahamic religions [Christianity, Islam and Judaism] and of dialogue among the three faiths."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.almanar.com.lb/newssite/NewsDetails.aspx?id=153389&language=en |title=President Sleiman Condemns Plans to Burn Holy Quran 08/09/2010 |publisher=Al-ManarTV |date=September 8, 2010 |accessdate=September 13, 2010 }}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
{{flag|Pakistan}}'s government strongly condemned the plan. Pakistani Foreign Ministry spokesman Abdul Basit told reporters "This is against the spirit of any religion, the government and the people of Pakistan, including Pakistani Christians, are outraged at this planned, shameful act by a self-proclaimed pastor."<ref>{{cite news |title=Pakistan Strongly Condemns Planned Quran Burning |url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/asia/Pakistan-Strongly-Condemns-Planned-Quran-Burning-102540044.html |newspaper=Voice of America |date=September 9, 2010 |accessdate=October 3, 2010}}</ref>
{{flag|Palestine}}. In [[Gaza City|Gaza]], [[Hamas]] Prime Minister [[Ismail Haniyeh]] called Terry Jones a "crazy priest who reflects a crazy Western attitude toward Islam and the [[ummah|Muslim nation]]."<ref name="BBC10"/>
{{Flag|United States}}. President [[Barack Obama]] said "I just want [Jones] to understand that this stunt that he is talking about pulling could greatly endanger our young men and women in uniform who are in Iraq, who are in Afghanistan."<ref name="aljaz"/> He also said that the planned event was being used as an [[al-Qaeda]] recruitment tool,<ref name="Reuters"/> and urged that the Quran burning be cancelled because it violated U.S. principles of religious tolerance. The president also expressed frustration that under the law, nothing could be done other than citing the church under a local ordinance for public burnings.<ref name="Reuters">{{Cite news |author1=Alexander, David |author2=Spetalnick, Matt |title=Obama says planned Quran burning is boosting Qaeda |url=http://ca.reuters.com/article/topNews/idCATRE68820G20100909?sp=true |publisher=[[Reuters|Reuters Canada]] |date=September 9, 2010 |accessdate=September 10, 2010}}</ref>
{{flag|Vatican City}}. The [[Pontifical Council for Interreligious Dialogue]] issued a statement saying that the book burning would be "an outrageous and grave gesture".<ref>{{Cite news |title=Vatican Says Quran Buring [sic] Would Be 'Outrageous' |url=http://www.myfoxny.com/dpp/news/national/vatican-says-koran-buring-would-be-outrageous-newscore-20100908 |work= myfoxny.com |agency=[[Agence France-Presse|AFP]] |date=September 8, 2010}}</ref>
;Supranational bodies {{flag|NATO}}. [[Anders Fogh Rasmussen]], [[NATO]] Secretary General, said that the church's plans would violate NATO's values and might have a negative impact on the security of its soldiers.<ref name="bbc2010-11-07">{{Cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-south-asia-11209738 |title=Petraeus: Quran burning plan will endanger US troops |date=July 11, 2010 |publisher=BBC |accessdate=September 8, 2010}}</ref>
{{flag|Organisation of the Islamic Conference}} expressed deep concern and alarm at the burnings.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.oic-oci.org/topic_detail.asp?t_id=4135&x_key= |title=OIC Expresses Deep Concern and Alarm at reports of Dove World Outreach Center Church of Gainesville, Florida, USA to burn copies of the Holy Quran |publisher=Organization of the Islamic Conference |date=August 24, 2010}}</ref>
{{flag|United Nations}}. Secretary-General [[Ban Ki-moon]] said he was "deeply disturbed", adding that such a gesture would be intolerable by any religion.<ref>{{Cite news |title=UN chief Ban condemns Quran burning plan |url=http://www.nowlebanon.com/NewsArticleDetails.aspx?ID=200070 |work=[[Now Lebanon]] |agency=AFP |date=September 8, 2010}}</ref>
====Media reactions==== Some in the media attributed the event to [[silly season]] and [[Yellow journalism|sensationalism]].<ref name=ALJ910 />
James Poniewozik, of ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' gave a few reasons for media coverage of the event: "tiny groups of fringe idiots" often get coverage, presumably because the vast majority of readers find them strange and different. The event also happens to coincide with a seeming American "Islamophobia" and concern over the "Ground Zero mosque;" he also added that "This is, unfortunately, one of those cases in which, by having become news, the story is now making legitimate news." ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]''<nowiki>'</nowiki>s David Weigel, said reporters should "Ignore This Idiot" (the title of his blog post on the controversy). "[Jones] gets to hold the country, or at least the part of the country that pays attention to such news, hostage, with reporters getting the secretary of state and our general in Afghanistan on the record to condemn this nobody. Instead of dying in obscurity, he'll die a has-been. Good work." ''[[ABC News]]''<nowiki>'</nowiki> [[Chris Cuomo]] wrote that the "media gave life to this Florida burning ... and that was reckless." Roger Simon, a columnist for ''[[Politico (newspaper)|Politico]]'' responded to David Petraeus' remarks saying "The issue is not the images; it is the acts."<ref name=ALJ910>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/features/2010/09/2010910123534220284.html|title=Quran row feeds media frenzy|author=Evan Hill|date=September 10, 2010|publisher=[[Al Jazeera]]}}</ref>
Both the [[Associated Press]] and [[Fox News]] stated their intention to ignore it.<ref name=ALJ910 />
;Other media reactions The conservative ''[[Power Line|Powerline]]'' blog stated it was against the Qu'ran burning, but also said that "what gives rise to this dilemma, of course, is the fanaticism of radical Muslims, who have, indeed, responded violently to real or perceived slights to their religion." John Hinderaker, a lawyer and freelance writer, argued that "Perversely, the crazier radical Muslims behave, the more it benefits them (those burning the Qurans). Today it is burning Qurans, but the broader objective is to outlaw, de facto, any criticism of Islam." Another conservative writer [[Michelle Malkin]], echoed an article by [[Christopher Hitchens]], when she bemoaned "the eternal flame of Muslim outrage. When everything from sneakers to stuffed animals to comics to frescos to beauty queens to fast-food packaging to undies serves as dry tinder for [[Allah]]'s avengers, it's a grand farce to feign concern about the recruitment effect of a few burnt Qurans in the hands of a two-bit attention-seeker in Florida."
A [[Facebook]] page support the pastor's plan got more than 16,000 fans by eve of the event, while fans opposing the event numbered in the hundreds of thousands.<ref name="aljaz">{{cite web|author=Evan Hill |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/features/2010/09/2010910123534220284.html |title=Quran row feeds media frenzy |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=September 10, 2010 |accessdate=September 13, 2010}}</ref>
====Actions against Dove World Outreach Center==== The Gainesville fire department refused to grant the church a burning permit;<ref>{{cite web|url= http://lexappeal.org/post/1000243524/lex-weekly-for-august-23-2010-16-minutes-the|title = Lex Weekly|publisher = Lex Appeal|date = August 23, 2010}}</ref> regardless, the church planned to proceed with the event despite the potential fine.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.gainesville.com/article/20100818/ARTICLES/100819384/1118?Title=Gainesville-denies-Dove-World-a-permit-to-burn-Quran|title = Gainesville denies Dove World a permit to burn Quran|author = Chad Smith|publisher = Gainesville Sun|date = August 18, 2010}}</ref> Following the July 2010 announcement of the Quran burning, the bank holding a $140,000 mortgage loan on the church property, demanded immediate repayment of the balance, and the property insurance was canceled.<ref name=nytimes>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/08/26/us/26gainesville.html |title=Far From Ground Zero, Obscure Pastor Is Ignored No Longer|publisher=New York Times|first=Damien|last=Cave|date=August 25, 2010}}</ref> A lighted sign and an acrylic cross on the property were damaged by rocks.<ref name=AFP912>{{cite web |url=http://bigpondnews.com/articles/World/2010/09/12/No_Koran_burning_but_activists_gather_512077.html |title=No Quran burning but activists gather |date=September 12, 2010}} (this report was also carried on AFP via Yahoo News)</ref> On September 8, 2010, [[Rackspace]], the provider of web hosting service to the Dove World Outreach website, disconnected the site, citing a violation of their terms of use policy.<ref>{{Cite news |author=CNN Wire Staff |url=http://www.cnn.com/2010/US/09/08/florida.quran.reaction/index.html |title=Vatican: Quran burning 'outrageous' |publisher=CNN |date=September 9, 2010 |accessdate=September 9, 2010}}</ref> A spokesman for Rackspace told news media that the shutdown was not "a constitutional issue," it was "a contract issue." <ref>{{cite web |last=Deleon |first=Nicholas |url=http://www.crunchgear.com/2010/09/09/rackspace-pulls-the-plug-on-%E2%80%98burn-a-koran-day%E2%80%99-churchs-web-site/ |title=Rackspace Pulls The Plug On 'Burn A Quran Day' Church's Web Site |publisher=Crunchgear.com |date=September 9, 2010 |accessdate=September 9, 2010}}</ref>
The city of Gainesville has said it would charge the church $200,000, representing the cost of a security presence by the police department, the [[Alachua County]] Sheriff's Office, and some city public works employees.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.actionnewsjax.com/content/topstories/story/New-information-on-the-cost-of-cancelled-Koran/NfxZ-qEwrE-it5QSW7eWlg.cspx?rss=1|title=New information on the cost of cancelled Quran burning|publisher=Action 47 News/FOX News 30|date=September 17, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722144958/http://www.actionnewsjax.com/content/topstories/story/New-information-on-the-cost-of-cancelled-Koran/NfxZ-qEwrE-it5QSW7eWlg.cspx?rss=1|archivedate=July 22, 2011|df=mdy-all}}</ref> The Alachua County Sheriff's Office estimated that it spent $100,000 on providing security to Jones, and specifically assigned 160 of the 242 deputies on duty September 11 to police activities related to the planned burning.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.nypost.com/p/news/national/fla_pastor_who_threatened_bill_burn_iGqtFvetBpUVvqlzp3JF3M |title=Fla. pastor who threatened to burn Quran may get $200,000 security bill |publisher=New York Post |date=September 17, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100920204331/http://www.nypost.com/p/news/national/fla_pastor_who_threatened_bill_burn_iGqtFvetBpUVvqlzp3JF3M |archivedate=September 20, 2010 }}</ref>
====Death threats==== Jones said that he hoped the event would not lead to violence. He said that he had been receiving [[death threat]]s regularly since the event was announced.<ref name="nytimes"/> [[Evan Kohlmann]] of Flashpoint Global Partners, a firm that "tracks radical militant websites," said that a suicide bomber had threatened to drive a truck into the church and others had discussed setting the building on fire, though it was not known if the discussions were serious. The Wall Street Journal quoted an individual calling himself Abu Dujanah from a jihadist website, "Now, I wish to bomb myself in this church as revenge for the sake of [[Allah]]'s talk... And here I register my name here that I want to be an intended martyr."<ref name=FOX827 />
When death threats directed against Jones were mailed to ''[[The Gainesville Sun]]'' in a letter postmarked from Johnstown, Pa.,<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.gainesville.com/article/20100901/ARTICLES/9011007/1002|title = Letter says assassins plan to kill Dove World pastor|author = Chad Smith|publisher = The Gainesville Sun|date = September 1, 2010}}</ref> the American Muslim Association of North America issued a statement signed by 15 imams including Ahmed Al Mehdawi of the Islamic Center of Gainesville condemning the death threats.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.gainesville.com/article/20100901/ARTICLES/100909964/1109/sports|title = Blog: Muslim groups condemn threats against Dove World|author = Chad Smith|publisher = The Gainesville Sun|date = September 1, 2010}}</ref> During Jones's September 11 visit to New York, Police Commissioner [[Raymond Kelly|Ray Kelly]] said that police plan to keep a "close tab on him" for his own safety.<ref name=CNN911 />
In March 2013 the al-Qaeda English-language magazine ''[[Inspire (magazine)|Inspire]]'' published a poster stating "Wanted dead or alive for crimes against Islam" with a prominent image of Terry Jones.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.weeklystandard.com/blogs/al-qaeda-mag-publishes-wanted-dead-or-alive-list_704904.html |title=Al Qaeda Mag Publishes 'Wanted: Dead or Alive' List |publisher=The Weekly Standard |date=March 1, 2013 |accessdate=September 2, 2013}}</ref>
