====Other Quran desecration incidents==== Within hours of Jones's cancellation announcement on September 9, [[Westboro Baptist Church]] member Megan Roper announced via Twitter that the church would proceed with its own Quran-burning ceremony;<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.ocala.com/article/20100909/ARTICLES/100909743/1412?Title=Westboro-Baptish-Church-to-burn-Qurans-if-Dove-doesn-t|title = Westboro Baptist Church to burn Qurans if Dove doesn't |author=Chad Smith |publisher=Ocala.com |date=September 9, 2010}}</ref> Her mother said she was angry that the media had not covered WBC's 2008 Quran-burning similarly to its approach in 2010.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mcclatchydc.com/2010/09/09/100291/fred-phelps-daughter-westboro.html |title=Fred Phelps' daughter: 'Westboro Church has already burned Qurans' |author1=Donald Bradley |author2=Rick Montgomery |publisher=[[Kansas City Star]] via [[McClatchy News Service|McClatchy]] |date=September 9, 2010}}</ref> Phelps announced his intention to "burn the Quran and the doomed [[Flag of the United States|American flag]] at noon on September 11", subsequently doing so without incident.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.csmonitor.com/USA/Society/2010/0910/Florida-church-may-not-burn-Qurans-but-Kansas-church-says-it-will|title=Florida church may not burn Qurans, but Kansas church says it will |author=Brad Knickerbocker |date=September 10, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://cjonline.com/news/local/2010-09-11/wbcs_flames_produce_little_heat |title=WBC's flames produce little heat |author=Phil Anderson |date=September 11, 2010 |publisher=Topeka Capital-Journal |access-date=September 15, 2010 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/5sgHGJSdN?url=http://cjonline.com/news/local/2010-09-11/wbcs_flames_produce_little_heat# |archive-date=September 12, 2010 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
Duncan Philp of the Wyoming Tyranny Response Team obtained a permit to protest outside the [[Wyoming State Capitol]] from 11:00 to 13:00 on September 11. He expressed the intent to set a Quran on fire at noon, or, if the public burning was not permitted, to tear up the Quran and move the pieces in a garbage can to a private business to be burned. Members of the local [[Unitarian Universalism|Unitarian Universalist Church]] planned a counter-protest.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/2010/09/10/2010-09-10_pastor_terry_jones_proposed_koran_burning_on_911_is_being_copied_by_protestors_a.html |title=Pastor Terry Jones' 9/11 Quran burn fuels copycats in U.S., violent protests abroad |author=Aliyah Shahid |publisher=New York Daily News |date=September 10, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wyomingnews.com/articles/2010/09/09/news/18local_09-09-10.txt |title=Protester plans to burn Quran on Capitol steps |author=Becky Orr |publisher=Wyoming Tribune Eagle |accessdate=September 11, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wyomingtrt.com/burnakoran.html |title=Wyoming TRT national burn a Quran day September 11th |publisher=Wyoming Tyranny Response Team |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100913050510/http://www.wyomingtrt.com/burnakoran.html |archivedate=September 13, 2010 |df=mdy-all }} (rally announcement)</ref> Later the group described the exercise as a test of free speech and said they would take no action on state property.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.kgwn.tv/_videos/pages/201009114219.html |title=Quran Burning Takes a Turn |date=September 11, 2010 |publisher=KGWN-TV }}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ''(video plays, with some difficulty, in Internet Explorer)''</ref>
In [[Pueblo West]], a Quran was bolted to a stop sign during the weekend of September 11–12.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newsfirst5.com/news/koran-bolted-to-stop-sign-in-pueblo-west/# |title=Quran bolted to stop sign in Pueblo West |author=John Romero |publisher=NBC Five News First }}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
In Nashville, Evangelical pastor Bob Old and another preacher burned a Quran with lighter fluid in a private yard.<ref name=REU911>{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE68709M20100911 |title=Tensions over Quran spark isolated incidents on 9/11 |author1=Basil Katz |author2=Edith Honan |publisher=Reuters |date=September 11, 2010}}</ref> A group of protesters came to his house, but there were no confrontations. He decided not to post the burning to YouTube.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newschannel5.com/global/story.asp?s=13138280 |title=Pastor Says He Did Burn Quran |publisher=NewsChannel 5 |date=September 11, 2010}}</ref>
In lower Manhattan, protesters against the "[[Ground Zero mosque]]" took some actions against the Quran.<ref name=REU911 /><ref name=NYD911>[http://www.nydailynews.com/ny_local/2010/09/11/2010-09-11_man_ignites_koran_near_ground_zero_apparently_prompted_by_florida_pastor_terry_j.html Man ignites Quran near Ground Zero, apparently prompted by Terry Jones; crowd appalled by zealot]. Nydailynews.com (September 11, 2010). Retrieved April 30, 2011.</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/blog/watercooler/2010/sep/11/video-koran-set-fire-ground-zero/ |title=Video: Quran set on fire at Ground Zero |author=Kerry Picket|publisher=[[Washington Times]]}}</ref> The latter, who refused to identify himself, was reported to have been "escorted away to safety a few blocks away" by police after burning a few pages.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/breaking-news/man-burns-koran-pages-at-site-of-controversial-new-york-city-mosque/story-e6frf7jx-1225919022334|title=Man burns Quran pages at site of controversial New York City mosque |author1=Joe Walker |author2=Ann Sutherland |publisher=Herald Sun/New York Post |date=September 13, 2010}}</ref> He was subsequently recognized as a New Jersey transit worker, and was fired by the agency for violating a code of conduct,<ref>The code of conduct has been tentatively identified ({{cite web |url=http://gothamist.com/2010/09/16/koran-burning.php |title=Christie Defends, Others Question Firing of Quran-Burner |author=Ben Yakas |date=September 16, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120504042530/http://gothamist.com/2010/09/16/koran-burning.php |archivedate=May 4, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}) as the {{cite web |url=http://www.state.nj.us/ethics/docs/ethics/uniformcode.pdf |title=State of New Jersey Uniform Ethics Code }}</ref> despite being off-duty while at a protest in New York. This in turn has drawn criticism from New Jersey state senator [[Ray Lesniak]] and the [[American Civil Liberties Union]], which said a person employed in a non-policy related role cannot be fired for off-the-job political expression.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://newyork.cbslocal.com/2010/09/15/burning-koran-pages-gets-worker-fired/#comment-30736 |title=NJ Senator: Quran Burner Shouldn't Lose His Job |date=September 15, 2010 |publisher=CBS New York}}</ref>

Thanks!-->{{Anchor|Repent Amarillo Quran incident}} Also, in [[Texas]], on the ninth anniversary of the 9/11 terrorist attacks, a group of protesters made up of Christians, Muslims, Buddhists and atheists gathered at [[Sam Houston Park]] in order to challenge the plan of evangelist David Grisham, director of a Christian activist group to burn the Quran. An activist named Isom took away the Quran from Grisham and he left the park.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/39149635/ns/us_news-life/|title='Dude, you have no Quran'|publisher=MSNBC.com|date=September 15, 2010}}</ref>
Alex Stewart, a research lawyer in [[Brisbane]], Australia, purportedly rolled "[[joint (cannabis)|joints]]" using pages from the Quran and the Bible and smoked them in a [[YouTube]] video. The video was quickly removed from YouTube.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/afp/australiausreligionislam|title=Australia lawyer "smokes" Quran, Bible pages|publisher=Yahoo! News|date=September 14, 2010}}</ref> but many copies have since been posted and related links. According to Michael Cope, president of the [[Queensland Council for Civil Liberties]], "I don't think on the face of it that what he's done is an offence...nor do we think it should be," referring to the [[Queensland Anti-Discrimination Act]]. Stewart was placed on leave from [[Queensland University of Technology]], where he worked, by its vice-chancellor Peter Coaldrake pending a review under the university's code of conduct. Coaldrake said, "The university is obviously extremely, extremely unhappy and disappointed that this sort of incident should occur... It may have occurred in the individual's private time or on a weekend – it doesn't matter... There is always, in the community, collateral damage to these sorts of things."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.smh.com.au/breaking-news-national/bible-and-koran-smoking-lawyer-on-leave-20100913-1577v.html|title=Bible and Quran smoking lawyer on leave|author=AAP|date=September 13, 2010|work=The Sydney Morning Herald}}</ref> Stewart was returned to his job on September 22 after he had "apologised unreservedly" for the nature of the incident.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.couriermail.com.au/news/queensland/alex-stewart-the-koarn-smoking-lawyer-returns-to-work-at-queensland-university-of-technology/story-e6freoof-1225927893520 |title=Alex Stewart, the Quran-smoking lawyer, returns to work at Queensland University of Technology |author=Margaret Wenham |publisher=Courier-Mail |date=September 22, 2010<!-- 2:16PM-->}}</ref>
With [[mainstream media]] sources pledging to limit coverage of Quran burning, individuals took to YouTube. A YouTube spokesperson indicated that they do not prescreen videos, and generally responded to complaints about the issue by placing warnings about offensive material.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/afp/20100910/tc_afp/usattacksreligionislammediarightsinternet_20100910164132 |title=Quran burning threat ignites debate on media coverage |publisher=AFP |author=Chris Lefkow |date=September 10, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://blogs.forbes.com/andygreenberg/2010/09/10/will-youtube-censor-burn-a-koran-day-and-should-it/ |title=Will YouTube Censor "Burn A Quran Day"? And Should It? |author=Andy Greenberg |publisher=Forbes |date=September 10, 2010}}</ref> The [[Huffington Post]] questioned why the Quran-burning story was treated as major news, while many news outlets did not cover the prosecution of 12 soldiers for crimes including the premeditated murder of Afghan civilians, possibly for sport, and the keeping of body parts as trophies.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/victoria-jones/cable-news-blew-it-us-sol_b_713758.html |title=Cable News Blew It! US Soldiers Charged – Murder, Cover Up, Trophies, Skulls, Fingers! |author=Victoria Jones |date=September 15, 2010 |work=Huffington Post}}</ref> [[Keith Richburg]], a journalist for the [[Washington Post]] in Beijing, said that professional journalists "act as a filter on what information should be released or left out so that it does not hurt society", and warned that digital media allows the role of media as a gatekeeper to be undermined.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nationmultimedia.com/home/2010/09/12/politics/Beware-of-digital-media-veteran-says-30137799.html |title=Beware of digital media, veteran says |author=Kornchanok Raksaseri |publisher=The Nation |date=September 12, 2010 |access-date=September 14, 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121009171427/http://www.nationmultimedia.com/home/2010/09/12/politics/Beware-of-digital-media-veteran-says-30137799.html# |archive-date=October 9, 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> American counterintelligence experts said that with no images of Quran burnings televised during the September 11 anniversary, that violent anti-American protests in Muslim countries would soon fizzle.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newsweek.com/blogs/declassified/2010/09/16/with-no-qurans-burned-anti-american-ire-recedes.html |title=With No Qurans Burned, Anti-American Ire Recedes |date=September 16, 2010 |publisher=Newsweek}}</ref>
A Quran was found shot and burned in the driveway of the Annoor Mosque in [[Knoxville, Tennessee]]. Knoxville police and the FBI began investigating the incident as a possible civil rights violation, a threat, and a hate crime. A YouTube video posted by a user "MuslimKnoxvilleOrg" showing the burning of a Quran stuffed with bacon and doused with lighter fluid was also being investigated, though it was not immediately connected to the mosque.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wbir.com/news/local/story.aspx?storyid=134130&provider=rss |title=Knoxville mosque leaders downplay shot, burned Quran |author=Anthony Welsch |date=September 13, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FvJcv1DQya4 |title=How to cook/ burn a Quran and send it to hell. Knoxville, Tennessee Style! |author=MuslimKnoxvilleOrg |publisher=YouTube}} ''(original video)''</ref> According to Knoxville [[FBI Special Agent]] Richard L. Lambert, "The fact that the burnt and shot Quran was placed on mosque property can be construed as a threat of force ... The issue comes down to determining what was the perpetrator's intent." Federal charges were considered, based on a 1968 law making it an offense "to use force to prevent anyone from carrying out their religious beliefs"; state charges were also considered under Tennessee civil rights law prohibiting intimidation, and misdemeanor offenses such as [[disorderly conduct]] were also explored.<ref name=RNN924 />
In Michigan, a burned Quran was found in front of the Islamic Center of East Lansing. Local police and the FBI were called in to investigate. Dawud Walid, director of Michigan's Islamic council chapter said, "This is no different than someone painting a swastika on a synagogue or burning a cross on a black church."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.upi.com/Top_News/US/2010/09/13/Burned-Koran-found-in-Michigan/UPI-44151284379711/ |title=Burned Quran found in Michigan |date=September 13, 2010 |publisher=UPI}}</ref> On September 21, the County Prosecutor said the man who turned himself in for the incident would not face charges because the act was not a crime under Michigan's criminal code.<ref name=RNN924>{{cite web |url=http://www.presstelegram.com/rss/ci_16166604?source=rss |title=Is it free speech or intimidation? |author=Omar Sacirbey |publisher=Religion News Service |date=September 24, 2010}}</ref>
On the north side of Chicago, Illinois, a burned Quran and a letter were found on the sidewalk outside the Muslim Community Center over the September 11–12 weekend, and were turned over to be investigated by Chicago police bomb and arson unit.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wbez.org/Content.aspx?audioID=44451|title=Hate Mail Follows Burnt Quran at Local Mosque|author=Odette Yousef|date=September 15, 2010|publisher=WBEZ91.5|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100918055800/http://wbez.org/Content.aspx?audioID=44451|archivedate=September 18, 2010|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/09/15/burned-quran-found-outsid_n_718194.html |title=Burned Quran Found Outside Muslim Community Center In Chicago |author=Will Guzzardi |publisher=Huffington Post |date=September 15, 2010}}</ref>
===Cancellation (postponement) and aftermath=== On September 9, Jones announced the cancellation of the event, and a plan to fly to New York to meet with the Imam of Park51, Feisal Abdul Rauf.<ref name="yahoocancel" /> In an interview on the morning of September 11, the day of the intended protest, he said, "We will definitely not burn the Quran...Not today, not ever."<ref name=CNN911>{{cite news |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2010/US/09/11/new.york.jones/index.html?hpt=T1 |title=Florida pastor calls off Quran burning |author=CNN wire staff |date=September 11, 2010}}</ref> Despite the cancellation, visiting protesters from both sides attempted to reach the rally, but a heavy police presence dominated the area. A visitor from Atlanta who attempted to burn a Quran had his book and lighter seized by police.<ref name=AFP912 />
The World Evangelical Alliance later contacted Jones, asking him to apologize for the planned Quran burning. In a public statement, he refused, saying, "We will not repent for standing up for the gospel", adding that Christian churches "have lost their guts to stand up for Christianity. But instead, they bow down to the political powers and the false doctrines of the nations."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.clickorlando.com/news/25036179/detail.html |title=Gainesville Pastor: 'We Will Not Repent' |author=Internet Broadcasting Systems |publisher=Clickorlando.com (WKMG Local 6) |date=September 16, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111006004804/http://www.clickorlando.com/news/25036179/detail.html |archivedate=October 6, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
As of October 22, 2010, Jones collected a new car which was offered as a reward to Jones in a "quirky radio" ad by a New Jersey [[Hyundai]] dealership owned by former [[New York Giants]], [[Brad Benson]] if Jones did not burn Qurans. Jones said he did not learn of the reward until several weeks after canceling the burning.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://videos.nj.com/star-ledger/2010/10/pastor_terry_jones_swings_by_n.html |author=Brian Donohue |publisher=The Star Ledger |date=October 22, 2010 |title=Pastor Terry Jones swings by N.J. to collect his free car from dealer Brad Benson |accessdate=December 28, 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101230005604/http://videos.nj.com/star-ledger/2010/10/pastor_terry_jones_swings_by_n.html# |archive-date=December 30, 2010 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Jones donated the car to charity.
On January 19, 2011, it was announced that Jones had been banned from entering the [[United Kingdom]] by the British [[Home Secretary]] [[Theresa May]]. Jones had been invited to give a speech for a Right-Wing group England is Ours in [[Milton Keynes]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-12231832 |title=US pastor Terry Jones banned from entering UK |date=January 19, 2011 |work=[[BBC Online]] |accessdate=April 2, 2011}}</ref>
=={{anchor|2011 burning of the Quran}} 2011 burning of the Quran== On March 20, 2011, [[Dove World Outreach Center]] held a trial which they called "International Judge the Quran Day".<ref name=judge-the-koran-day>[http://www.doveworld.org/blog/2011/03/international-judge-the-koran-day-%E2%80%A6-and-the-execution-burn-it International Judge the Quran Day … and the execution: burn it! | Dove World Outreach Center] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110404120739/http://www.doveworld.org/blog/2011/03/international-judge-the-koran-day-%E2%80%A6-and-the-execution-burn-it |date=April 4, 2011 }}. Doveworld.org. Retrieved April 30, 2011.</ref> Jones played the part of a "judge", wearing traditional robes.<ref name=judge-the-koran-day/> The Quran was placed on trial for six hours, charging it with responsibility for violence.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/nation/la-na-koran-pastor-20110402,0,4120847.story |title=Pastor of church that burned Quran calls Afghan mob killings 'very tragic'|publisher=Los Angeles Times |first=Richard |last=Fausset |date=April 1, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2011/03/22/national/main20045858.shtml |title=Quran burned after Fla. church "trial" |date=March 22, 2011 |work=CBS News |accessdate=April 2, 2011}}</ref> At the end of the "trial" the jury found the Quran guilty of all charges and "sentenced" to burning.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.ksdk.com/news/article/250877/28/Pastor-Terry-Jones-oversees-Quran-burning-outside-Florida-church |title=Pastor Terry Jones oversees Quran burning outside Florida church |last=Held |first=Kevin |author2=Adelle M. Banks |date=March 22, 2011 |publisher=ksdk.com |accessdate=April 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120903233605/http://www.ksdk.com/news/article/250877/28/Pastor-Terry-Jones-oversees-Quran-burning-outside-Florida-church |archivedate=September 3, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Pastor Wayne Sapp then "executed" the Quran by burning it.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.newsi.es/holy-quran-burning-by-terry-jones-creates-tensions-all-over-the-muslim-world/883084/ |title=Holy Quran Burning By Terry Jones Creates Tensions All over the Muslim World |last=Barclay |first=Joey |date=March 23, 2011 |publisher=Newsi.es |accessdate=April 2, 2011}}</ref>
Jones sought a permit in April 2011 to hold a rally at the Islamic Center of America in [[Dearborn, Michigan]]. A jury sided with prosecutors, ruling that Jones and Sapp would breach the peace. Judge Mark Somers set the bond for each man at $1, which they refused to pay. Somers remanded them to jail. Jones was barred from the area of the mosque for three years.<ref>Niraj Warikoo [http://www.freep.com/article/20110422/NEWS02/110422014/Judge-jails-Jones-refusing-pay-bond-bars-him-from-mosque-3-years Terry Jones goes free on $1 bond after jailing; judge bars him from mosque for 3 years], ''[[Detroit Free Press]]'', April 22, 2011</ref>
On November 11, 2011, Wayne County Circuit Court Judge Robert Ziolkowski vacated the "breach of peace" ruling against Terry Jones and Wayne Sapp on the grounds that they were denied due process. Both men's criminal records have since been expunged.<ref>{{cite web|author=Jeff T. Wattrick |url=http://www.mlive.com/news/detroit/index.ssf/2011/11/judge_vacates_breach_of_peace.html |title=Judge vacates 'breach of peace' judgement against Terry Jones |publisher=MLive.com |date=November 11, 2011 |accessdate=September 2, 2013}}</ref>
===Reactions=== {{see also|2011 Mazar-i-Sharif attack}}
On March 24 [[Hamid Karzai]], [[President of Afghanistan]], publicly condemned the act. Some diplomats believed that most Afghans learned of the incident through Karzai's announcement.<ref>Trofimov, Yaroslav. (April 26, 2011) [https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703806304576240643831942006?mod=WSJ_hp_MIDDLENexttoWhatsNewsSecond Petraeus Says Quran Burning Endangers War Effort - WSJ.com]. Online.wsj.com. Retrieved April 30, 2011.</ref> On April 2, crowds chanted "Death to Karzai!" as well as "[[Death to America]]!"<ref name="wsj4april">[https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703806304576240643831942006?mod=WSJ_WSJ_News_BlogsModule Petraeus Says Quran Burning Endangers War Effort], ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'', April 4, 2011.</ref> After a sermon on April 1 in the city's main mosque, at least 12 people were killed by angry demonstrators in [[Mazar-i-Sharif]], [[Afghanistan]],<ref name="wsj4april"/><ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/UN-Staff-Killed-During-Afghan-Protest-119063989.html |title=UN Staff Killed During Afghan Protest |publisher=[[Voice of America]] |date=April 1, 2011 |accessdate=April 1, 2011}}</ref> including five Nepalese security guards and three other members of staff working for the [[United Nations Assistance Mission in Afghanistan]] ([[UNAMA]]).<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-south-asia-12940014 UN staff killed during protest in northern Afghanistan], ''[[BBC News]]'', April 1, 2011.</ref> Jones denied responsibility.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-12940596 Pastor Terry Jones: 'We are not responsible'], ''[[BBC News]]'', April 1, 2011.</ref><ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/apr/01/un-staff-afghanistan-mazar-sharif-killed-quran UN staff killed in Afghanistan amid protests over Quran burning], Jon Boone in Kabul, ''[[The Guardian]]'', April 1, 2011.</ref> [[Pajhwok Afghan News]] reported that the dead included Norwegian, Romanian and Swedish nationals, two of them decapitated.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.pajhwok.com/en/2011/04/01/10-un-workers-killed-beheaded-mazar-attack |title=10 UN workers killed, beheaded in Mazar attack |publisher=Pajhwok Afghan News |date=April 1, 2011 |accessdate=April 1, 2011}}</ref> BBC quoted police general, Abdul Rafu Taj, as saying that "according to the initial reports... none were beheaded", and that they were shot in the head.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-south-asia-12944851|work=BBC News|title=Afghanistan: Deadly Kandahar protest at Quran burning|date=April 2, 2011}}</ref> Up to 2,000 protesters took to the streets on April 2 in [[Kandahar]], chanting anti-U.S. slogans. The protesters burned several vehicles and hurled stones at police who were trying to control the mob. They also torched a girls' high school and burned down a school bus in the centre of the city. Security forces killed nine protesters and injured 73.<ref>[http://www.monstersandcritics.com/news/southasia/news/article_1630274.php/9-killed-73-injured-in-Koran-protest-in-Kandahar "9 killed, 73 injured in Quran protest in Kandahar"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110405224503/http://www.monstersandcritics.com/news/southasia/news/article_1630274.php/9-killed-73-injured-in-Koran-protest-in-Kandahar |date=April 5, 2011 }}, ''Monsters and Critics'' (April 2, 2011). Retrieved April 30, 2011.</ref> Smaller protests occurred in other cities.<ref>Associated, The. (April 30, 2011) [https://www.npr.org/2011/04/03/135086383/quran-burning-protests-rage-in-afghanistan?ft=1&f=1001 Quran-Burning Protests Rage In Afghanistan]. NPR. Retrieved April 30, 2011.</ref>
The [[Gambia]]n government has called for the arrest of Terry Jones. Ebrima O. Camara, the secretary general and head of the civil service, described the burning as "heinous" and asked for prosecution to proceed "as soon as possible".<ref>[http://allafrica.com/stories/201104130750.html "Gambia: Terry Jones Should Be Prosecuted Says Gambia Gov't, As It Condemns Qur'an Burning"], allAfrica.com (April 13, 2011). Retrieved April 30, 2011.</ref>
An affiliate website of Iran's [[Iranian Revolutionary Guard|Revolution Guard Cyber Defense Command]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gerdab.ir/fa/content/3 |title=معرفي مركز بررسي جرائم سازمان يافته |publisher=Gerdab.ir |accessdate=September 15, 2012}}</ref> quoted<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gerdab.ir/fa/news/889/%D8%AA%D9%88%D8%B2%D9%8A%D8%B9-%DA%AF%D8%B3%D8%AA%D8%B1%D8%AF%D9%87-%D8%A7%D9%86%D8%AC%D9%8A%D9%84-%D9%88-%D8%AA%D9%88%D8%B1%D8%A7%D8%AA-%D8%AF%D8%B1-%DA%A9%D8%B4%D9%88%D8%B1 |title=توزيع گسترده انجيل و تورات در کشور |publisher=Gerdab.ir |accessdate=September 15, 2012}}</ref> a report by the newspaper ''Vatan-e Emrooz'' that claimed Iranian border patrols were burning copies of "smuggled" Bibles in Iran.<ref>''Vatan-e Emrooz'' pp.3 of Volume 434<br>وطن امروز/شماره 434/صفحه3</ref> On March 25, 2011, the Iranian Ambassador to the United Nations, [[Mohammad Khazaee]], condemned the burning and called for Jones's prosecution.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/171662.html |title=Iran calls for trial of Quran burners |publisher=Press TV |date=March 25, 2011}}</ref>
In southern [[Lebanon]], students protested peacefully with [[Shia]] sheikh Hassan al-Zayyat outside the Lebanese International University to construct the largest Quran on Earth, weighing 100 kg.<ref>[http://www.presstv.ir/detail/175705.html "Lebanese students slam desecration of Qur'an"], Presstv.ir (April 19, 2011). Retrieved April 30, 2011.</ref> Lebanese Shia militant group [[Hezbollah]] has put a $2.4 million bounty on the head of pastor Terry Jones, according to the FBI.<ref>Mann, Camille. (April 4, 2011) [http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-504083_162-20050517-504083.html "Pastor Terry Jones receiving death threats after Quran burning"], CBS News. Retrieved April 30, 2011.</ref>
On March 22, 2011, Pakistanis protested in the [[Punjab, India|Punjab]] Christian neighborhoods and burned tires in front of a church.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cathnewsindia.com/2011/03/24/christians-in-fear-after-qur%E2%80%99an-burning/ |title=Christians in fear after Qur'an burning |publisher=Union of Catholic Asian News |date=March 24, 2011 }}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> On March 22, 2011, Amir Hamza, the leader of Pakistan's banned Islamic organization [[Jama'at-ud-Da'wah]], issued a $2.2 million [[fatwā]] for anyone who kills pastor Terry Jones.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/us/US-pastor-supervises-Quran-burning-sparks-outrage-in-Pak/articleshow/7764048.cms |title=US pastor supervises Quran burning, sparks outrage in Pak |date=March 22, 2011 |work=Times Of India |accessdate=April 2, 2011 |location=Washington/Islamabad}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-03-22/us/29174030_1_american-pastor-terry-jones-quran-religious-groups |title=JuD announces Rs 10 crore for killing US pastor over Quran burning |publisher=PTI |date=March 22, 2011<!--, 08.38pm IST-->}}</ref> On March 25, 2011, protests erupted in [[Pakistan]], where the [[Jamiat Ulema-e-Islam|Jamiat-e-Ulema-e-Islam]] organized province-wide protests, including a road blockage and burnings of effigies and American flags in the province of [[Sindh]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thenews.com.pk/TodaysPrintDetail.aspx?ID=37911&Cat=4&dt=3/25/2011 |title=Religious parties protest desecration of Quran |author=Shamim Bano |publisher=[[The News International]] |date=March 25, 2011}}</ref> A man desecrated the Bible at the gates of [[St. Anthony's Church, Lahore|Saint Anthony's Catholic Church]] in [[Lahore]] to "avenge" Jones' desecration of the Quran in Florida;<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.christianpost.com/news/muslim-desecrates-bible-in-pakistan-to-avenge-quran-burning-49767/ |title=Muslim Desecrates Bible in Pakistan to 'Avenge' Quran Burning |publisher=Christianpost.com |date=April 9, 2011 |accessdate=September 15, 2012}}</ref> he was arrested by Pakistani police. The President of the Pakistani Bishops' Conference, [[Excellency|His Excellency]], [[Lawrence Saldanha]], who currently serves as the [[Metropolitan Archbishop]] of the [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Lahore]], called for the arrest of Jones. Saldanha said Jones' burning of the Qu'ran has caused scandal and fury in the Muslim world and the deaths of more than 20 people. Archbishop Saldanha said the U.S. government should detain Jones.<ref>Simon Caldwell, [[Catholic News Service]], April 4, 2011</ref>
A [[South Africa]]n Islamic organization called Scholars for Truth turned to the country's courts to prevent a fellow-Muslim from burning Bibles in retaliation to threats by Jones to burn the Quran.<ref>{{cite web |author=Delia Robertson |url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/africa/southern/Muslim-Community-Seeks-to-Prevent-Bible-Burning-in-South-Africa-102629699.html |title=Muslim Community Seeks to Prevent Bible Burning in South Africa |publisher=Voanews.com |accessdate=September 15, 2012}}</ref>
[[President of the United States|United States President]] [[Barack Obama]] strongly condemned both the Quran burning, calling it an act of "extreme intolerance and bigotry", and the "outrageous" attacks by protesters, referring to them as "an affront to human decency and dignity". "No religion tolerates the slaughter and beheading of innocent people, and there is no justification for such a dishonorable and deplorable act."<ref>[http://www.dawn.com/2011/04/03/obama-condemns-quran-burning-%E2%80%98bigotry%E2%80%99.html Obama condemns Quran burning ‘bigotry’] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110408041104/http://www.dawn.com/2011/04/03/obama-condemns-quran-burning-%E2%80%98bigotry%E2%80%99.html |date=April 8, 2011 }}, ''[[Dawn]]'', April 3, 2011</ref> U.S. legislators, including Senate Majority Leader [[Harry Reid]], also condemned both the burning and the subsequent violence.<ref>[http://www.voanews.com/english/news/usa/US-Legislators-Condemn-Quran-Burning-Violent-Reaction-119148959.html US Legislators Condemn Quran Burning, Violent Reaction], ''[[Voice of America]]'', April 3, 2011</ref> Gen. [[David Petraeus]] said, "This was a surprise,"<ref name="wsj4april"/> and "That action was hateful; it was intolerant."<ref name="ABC">{{cite news |last=Vargas|first=Elizabeth| title=Terry Jones Receives Death Threats |url=https://news.yahoo.com/video/world-15749633/terry-jones-receives-death-threats-24780307 |newspaper=ABC News| date=April 4, 2011 |location=Gainesville}}</ref>
On 4 April 2011, two US soldiers were shot and killed by an Afghan policeman in an attack that was attributed to his anger over the burning of the Koran. The attacker was later killed in a shootout with NATO troops. The attacker has been called a hero and a martyr by some of the local community, with his grave becoming an unofficial shrine, and local mosques being named after him.<ref name="BBC News"/> However, at least one local cleric has stated that the attack could not be justified on religious grounds.<ref>{{cite news |publisher=BBC News |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-21774684 |title=The Afghan 'green-on-blue' attacker seen as a hero |date=March 29, 2013 |quote=But some are concerned about the way in which a man who killed two allied soldiers could become a hero and martyr overnight. Abdul Momen Makrit, a local cleric, says that there is no religious justification for an attack on soldiers who came to assist the country.}}</ref>

Manager, [[Evergreen International Aviation]]
Operations Lead, [[Sikorsky Aircraft]] }} '''Ernest Cary Brace''' (August 15, 1931 – December 5, 2014) was the longest-held civilian [[prisoner of war]] (POW) during the [[Vietnam War]].{{cite web|url=http://www.azcentral.com/news/election/mccain/articles/2007/03/01/20070301mccainbio-chapter3.html |title=McCain Profile: Prisoner of war |last1=Nowicki |first1=Dan |last2=Muller |first2=Bill |date=2007-03-01 |work=[[The Arizona Republic]] |publisher=azcentral.com |accessdate=2011-02-04 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wFYLPwdQ?url=http://www.azcentral.com/news/election/mccain/articles/2007/03/01/20070301mccainbio-chapter3.html |archivedate=2011-02-04 |deadurl=yes |df= }} A decorated [[United States Marine Corps|Marine Corps]] fighter pilot and [[Mustang (military officer)|mustang]], Brace was [[Courts-martial in the United States|court-martialed]] in 1961 for attempting to fake his own death. He flew as a civilian contract pilot before being captured in [[Laos]] in 1965 while flying supplies for [[USAID]]. He spent almost eight years as a POW and upon his release received a [[List of people pardoned or granted clemency by the President of the United States|Presidential Pardon]] in light of his good conduct. ==Military career== Brace was born in Detroit, Michigan in 1931. He enlisted in the Marine Corps in 1947 at age 15 as an aviation radar and radio technician. He earned his Pilot's Wings and his commission as a [[Second lieutenant|Second Lieutenant]] from the [[Aviation Cadet Training Program (USN)|Aviation Cadet School]], graduating in August 1951. During his tour in the [[Korean War]] (April 1952 - March 1953), he flew more than 100 missions.{{cite web|url=http://www.heraldandnews.com/news/article_4d204f12-d9bc-11df-86f4-001cc4c03286.html |title=Aviation Hall of Honor inducts local|publisher=[[Herald and News]]|date=18 October 2010|accessdate=2013-05-31}}{{Cite web|title=Ernest Brace: War hero court-martialled for desertion who became the longest-serving civilian prisoner of war in Vietnam|first=Emily|last=Langer|date=15 December 2014|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/ernest-brace-war-hero-court-martialled-for-desertion-who-became-the-longest-serving-civilian-9926791.html|website=[[The Independent]]}} While assigned to [[VMFA-121|Marine Attack Squadron 121]] in November 1952, Second Lieutenant Brace participated in a [[Dive bomber|dive-bombing]] attack against a Korean hydroelectric plant. Brace received surface-to-air fire as he took low-altitude reconnaissance imagery of the bombing results. He was able to fly his damaged [[Douglas A-1 Skyraider|AD-3 Skyraider]] clear of the Korean Peninsula, crashing in the Sea of Japan where he was rescued by ''[[USS Kidd (DD-661)|USS Kidd]]''. For his courage and initiative, Brace was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross.{{cite web |author=Jane Blakeney |url=http://projects.militarytimes.com/citations-medals-awards/recipient.php?recipientid=28065 |title=Valor awards for Ernest C. Brace |publisher=[[Gannett Government Media|Military Times]] |date= |accessdate=2013-07-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140221172606/http://projects.militarytimes.com/citations-medals-awards/recipient.php?recipientid=28065 |archivedate=2014-02-21 |df= }} Years later, Brace (then a [[Captain (United States O-3)|captain]]) crashed his [[North American T-28 Trojan|T-28 Trojan]] into a cornfield near the mouth of the [[Choptank River]] near [[Cambridge, Maryland]] during a training flight on 3 January 1961. He fled the scene but turned himself in ten days later once his empty flight-suit was found hidden in vegetation. Brace faced a court-martial and was charged with deliberately crashing his aircraft and faking his death so that his wife Patricia could collect insurance money to pay off debts.{{Cite news|title=Quantico to Open Brace Court-Martial|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1298&dat=19610705&id=7vFNAAAAIBAJ&sjid=qIoDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5576,141019|date=5 July 1961|newspaper=[[Free-Lance Star]]}} Brace pleaded guilty to ''unauthorized absence'' and was acquitted of the deliberate destruction of his aircraft.{{Cite news|newspaper=[[The Progress-Index|Petersburg Progress]]|title=Marine Pilot to Present Defense at Court Martial|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/petersburg-progress-index/1961-07-07/page-7|date=7 July 1961|page=7}} The court-martial ended his military career.{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1988-02-28/books/bk-265_1_marine-corps |title=Death Before Dishonor and Life After It|publisher=''[[Los Angeles Times]]''|date=1988-02-28|author=William C. Creasy|accessdate=2013-05-31}} ==Capture== {{Quote box |title = Prisoner in a Cage (excerpt) |quote = I'm just a prisoner in a cage; I have no name, I have no age. The guards don't even know what I've done, All they know, I'm a captured one. My feet are in stocks, my neck tied to a pole, What food I get is shoved through a hole; At night I lie down, and my hands are tied, The rope is stretched to a pole outside. |source = Ernest Brace{{Cite book|title=We Came Home|editor=Barbara Wyatt|year=1977|publisher=P.O.W. Publications}} |align = right |width = |border = |fontsize = 80% |bgcolor = cornsilk |style = |title_bg = |title_fnt = 80% |tstyle = center |qalign = center |qstyle = |quoted = |salign = |sstyle = }} Brace then worked as a civilian pilot for a number of companies before flying for [[BirdAir]], an airline contracted by the Thai [[Border Patrol Police]]. BirdAir also supported [[USAID]] interests in Southeast Asia. On 21 May 1965, he flew Royal Thai Army Sergeant Chaicharn, as well as other passengers and cargo to a dirt airstrip in the Northern Laotian village of Baum Lao in Muong Houn District.{{cite web|last=Conley |first=Margaret |url=http://abcnews.go.com/2020/story?id=5947378&page=1#.Uafd5kDCb0s |title=POW Remembers McCain and Tapping Through Walls in Hanoi Prison |publisher=[[ABC News]]|date=2008-10-03 |accessdate=2013-05-31}} Brace's aircraft, a [[Pilatus PC-6 Porter]], received small arms fire upon landing, rendering it incapable of taking off again.{{cite web|url=http://channel.nationalgeographic.com/channel/locked-up-abroad/articles/ernest-brace-longest-held-civilian-pow/ |title=Ernest Brace: Longest Held Civilian POW|publisher=[[National Geographic Channel|National Geographic]]|date= |accessdate=2013-05-31}} Both he and Chaicharn were immediately taken prisoner (either by the [[Vietnam People's Army]] or the [[Pathet Lao]]) and force-marched into the jungle from Boum Lao to Muong Hoc to Doi Sai, near [[Dien Bien Phu]].{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=s1VhNF19vJcC&pg=PA143&lpg=PA143&dq=ernest+brace+korea+pilot&source=bl&ots=naplwDT-5C&sig=taVfrRmTO4ZjMZWF39DPHrXdMg4&hl=en&sa=X&ei=2N2nUcbGA8jpigKV64HQBA&ved=0CE8Q6AEwBjgK#v=onepage&q=ernest%20brace%20korea%20pilot&f=false|title=An Enormous Crime: The Definitive Account of American POWs Abandoned in Southeast Asia|publisher=[[St. Martin's Griffin]]|last1=Hendon|first1=Bill|last2=Stewart|first2=Elizabeth|isbn=978-0-312-38538-5|page=143}} Brace was held in a bamboo cage with his limbs and neck bound to prevent escape. During his captivity he was beaten, interrogated, and faced with a [[mock execution]]. He escaped 6 June 1965 for a few days before being caught stealing food from a village. Upon his return to the cage his legs were put in stocks and bolted.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IGemFZmcn_AC&pg=PA648&lpg=PA648 |title=Honor Bound: American Prisoners of War in Southeast Asia, 1961–1973 |first1=Stuart I. |last1=Rochester | authorlink1 = Stuart Rochester |first2=Frederick T. |last2=Kiley |publisher=[[Naval Institute Press]] |year=1998 |accessdate=2013-06-05 |isbn=978-1-59114-738-1}} He escaped on 17 April 1966, and was recaptured in minutes. Next buried up to his chin for seven days, Brace hit his low point and attempted to hang himself on 10 December 1967. He was sent in October 1968 to a POW camp on the outskirts of [[Hanoi]] nicknamed The Plantation, where he met [[John McCain]] in the cell next to him.{{cite web|url=http://channel.nationalgeographic.com/channel/locked-up-abroad/videos/captured-by-the-enemy/ |title=Captured by the Enemy|publisher=[[National Geographic Channel|National Geographic]]|date=2013-03-22 |accessdate=2013-05-30}} Brace re-tells his story in Season 8 of ''[[Banged Up Abroad|Locked Up Abroad]]''{{cite web|last=Alfadl|first=Noura|url=http://thehill.com/blogs/in-the-know/in-the-know/294233-former-pows-mccain-and-brace-reunite-for-documentary-premiere |title=Former POWs McCain and Brace reunite for documentary premiere - The Hill's In The Know |publisher=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]] |date=2013-04-16 |accessdate=2013-05-30}} Like Jim Bedinger, he was sequestered from other prisoners because he had been captured in Laos.{{cite web|url=http://www.pownetwork.org/bios/b/b133.htm |title=Bio, Bedinger, Henry J |publisher=Pownetwork.org |date= |accessdate=2013-06-05}} Before [[Doug Hegdahl]]'s early release from the captivity, Brace contacted Hegdahl to ensure the outside world knew about the prisoners captured in Laos.{{r|monkeypaw}} ==Post-release== [[File:Ernie Brace POW medal.tif|right|thumb|300px|Brace was awarded the Prisoner of War Medal and the Purple Heart at a ceremony on [[Kingsley Field Air National Guard Base]] in 2013, forty years after his release.{{Cite web|url=http://www.kdrv.com/southern-oregon-man-honored-as-pow/|website=[[KDRV]]|title=Southern Oregon Man Honored as POW|date=August 16, 2013}}]] Brace was released on March 28, 1973, spending 7 years, 10 months and 7 days in captivity, making him the longest-held civilian [[POW]] in [[Vietnam]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.dtic.mil/dpmo/vietnam/reports/documents/pmsea_acc_p_name.pdf|title=U.S. Accounted-For from the Vietnam War: Prisoners of War, Escapees, Returnees and Remains Recovered|website=[[Defense Prisoner of War/Missing Personnel Office]]|date=2013-06-20}} Brace had not been listed as a prisoner during the past 7 years.{{cite web|url=http://tvblogs.nationalgeographic.com/2013/04/18/locked-up-abroad-where-are-they-now-ernie-brace-longest-held-civilian-pow-of-vietnam-war/ |title=Locked Up Abroad: Where Are They Now? Ernie Brace, Longest-Held Civilian POW of Vietnam War|publisher=''[[Banged Up Abroad|Locked Up Abroad]]'', [[National Geographic (magazine)|National Geographic]]|date=2013-04-18 |accessdate=2013-05-31}} His wife Patricia assumed her husband was dead and she remarried; a fact Brace found out at the processing station after his release.{{cite journal|last=Powell |first=Stewart M. |url=http://www.airforcemag.com/MagazineArchive/Pages/1999/August%201999/0899honor.aspx |title=Honor Bound |publisher=[[Air Force Magazine]]|date=August 1999 |volume=82 |issue=8 |accessdate=2013-05-31}} While receiving out-patient care in [[Naval Medical Center San Diego]], Brace met a nurse named Nancy stationed there. He married her and moved to her hometown of [[Klamath Falls, Oregon]] where he later resided.{{cite news|first=Lee|last=Juillerat|url=http://www.heraldandnews.com/breaking/article_ae25e500-a486-11e2-9dc3-0019bb2963f4.html?mode=jqm |title=Docudrama on Klamath Falls POW Wednesday on National Geographic |publisher=[[Herald and News]]|date=2013-04-13 |accessdate=2013-05-31}} In light of Brace's time as a POW, President Gerald Ford issued him a full pardon as well as an honorable discharge from the Marine Corps.{{Cite web|title=Nixon Pardon – Other requests for Pardon Arising from the Nixon Pardon|type=pdf|url=https://www.fordlibrarymuseum.gov/library/document/0019/4520707.pdf|website=[[Ford Presidential Library]]}}{{cite web|last=Brace |first=Ernest C. |url=https://www.kirkusreviews.com/book-reviews/ernest-c-brace/a-code-to-keep-the-true-story-of-americas-longe/ |title=A CODE TO KEEP: The True Story of America's Longest-Held Civilian Prisoner of War in Vietnam by Ernest C. Brace|publisher=[[Kirkus Reviews]]|date=1988-02-23 |accessdate=2013-06-05}} Brace, captured as a civilian, was nominated for the [[Prisoner of War Medal]] and the [[Purple Heart]] by [[James Stockdale|Admiral Stockdale]], the senior officer among US prisoners held during the Vietnam War. Because Department of Defense regulations prohibit civilians from receiving military awards, the nominations were denied four times. The most recent application in 2011, sent to the office of [[United States Secretary of the Navy]] [[Ray Mabus]] through fellow former POW John McCain was successful.{{Cite web|url=http://www.dvidshub.net/news/112426/ernest-c-brace-awarded-purple-heart-and-pow-medals#.VINyEDHF-So|title=Ernest C. Brace awarded Purple Heart and POW Medals|first=Marcin|last=Platek|date=August 22, 2013|website=[[Defense Video & Imagery Distribution System]]}} Brace commented that "these medals are the ones no one wants to get" as personal suffering is involved in qualifying for them.{{Cite news|url=http://www.173fw.ang.af.mil/shared/media/document/AFD-130918-039.pdf|p=2|title=Klamath Falls local honored for Vietnam captivity|journal=Kingsley Chronicle|volume=6|issue=5|date=September 2013|publisher=[[Oregon Air National Guard]]|first=Jefferson|last=Thompson}} Brace worked for a few years in the late 1970s as a manager for [[Evergreen International Aviation]], supporting aviation contracts for the United Nations in South Vietnam, Africa, and Mexico. He went on to work as an operations lead for [[Sikorsky Aircraft]] with other overseas contracts.{{Cite book|last=Brace|first=Ernest C.| title=Monkey Paw Soup: And Tales of Drugs, Thugs, Revolution, & War|publisher=Ernest C. Brace|location= |year=2012| isbn=978-0-615-59019-6}} In 2014, [[Klamath Community College]] awarded Brace an honorary associate degree in Aviation Science. The college is also considering naming their new veterans' center in his name.{{Cite news|url=http://www.heraldandnews.com/news/kcc-pays-tribute-to-pow-honors-brace-with-degree/article_63d59c0c-6aff-11e4-8a06-0b6c0ca141ee.html|title=KCC pays tribute to POW, honors Brace with degree|newspaper=[[Herald and News]]|date=November 13, 2014|first=Holly|last=Dillemuth}} He died on December 5, 2014 of a pulmonary embolism.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/09/us/ernest-brace-civilian-pilot-held-as-pow-in-vietnam-dies-at-83.html|title=Ernest Brace, Civilian Pilot Held as P.O.W. in Vietnam, Dies at 83|first=Douglas|last=Martin|date=December 8, 2014|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]}}{{cite news|url=http://www.heraldandnews.com/breaking/vietnam-pow-war-hero-ernie-brace-dies/article_4da0c9c4-7e56-11e4-b0d7-8bb3945a54f2.html|title=Services Monday for Vietnam POW, war hero, Ernie Brace|newspaper=[[Herald and News]]|date=December 8, 2014}} ==See also== *[[Floyd James Thompson]], the longest held POW in United States history, spending nearly nine years in captivity in Vietnam. *[[Everett Alvarez Jr.]] the second longest-held POW in United States history, spending 8.5 years in captivity in Vietnam. ==Autobiographies== *{{Cite book | last=Brace | first=Ernest C. | title=A Code to Keep: The true story of America's longest held civilian prisoner of war in Vietnam | publisher=[[St. Martin's Press]]| location=New York | year=1988 | isbn=0-7090-3560-8}} *{{Cite book | last=Brace | first=Ernest C. | title=Monkey Paw Soup: And Tales of Drugs, Thugs, Revolution, & War|publisher=Ernest C. Brace|location= | year=2012| isbn=978-0-615-59019-6}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *[http://www.pownetwork.org/bios/b/b603.htm Bio at pownetwork.org] *[http://www.azcentral.com/news/specials/mccain/articles/0301mccainbio-chapter3.html Prisoner of war] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Brace, Ernest C.}} [[Category:1931 births]] [[Category:2014 deaths]] [[Category:American Marine Corps personnel of the Korean War]] [[Category:American Marine Corps personnel of the Vietnam War]] [[Category:Shot-down aviators]] [[Category:Vietnam War prisoners of war]] [[Category:United States Marine Corps personnel who were court-martialed]] [[Category:Recipients of American presidential pardons]]

{{Italicize title}} [[File:Feria Nacional de San Marcos 2012 3.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Feria Nacional de San Marcos in 2012]]
The '''''Feria Nacional de San Marcos''''' ('''San Marcos Fair''') is a national [[fair]] held in the [[Mexico|Mexican]] [[States of Mexico|state]] of [[Aguascalientes]] every year for three (or sometimes four) weeks. Most of the events related to the fair, however, occur in the city of [[Aguascalientes, Aguascalientes|Aguascalientes]], the state capital. The exact date of the fair varies every year but is set around April 25, the [[Feast Day]] of [[Mark the Evangelist|San Marcos]].
Initially the fair was tied to the ''[[vendimia]]'' (harvesting of grapes) since wine production used to be an important activity in Aguascalientes. Nowadays, it is an important tourist attraction that is heavily associated with [[bullfighting]] and [[cockfighting]]. It is estimated that seven million people visit the fair every year and as a consequence hotels are usually filled to capacity, however some locals rent out their houses to visitors and go on vacation during this time.
==Activities== [[File:San marcos bullfight 01.jpg|thumbnail|left|Bullfight at the 2010 Fair]]
The San Marcos National Fair is organized by an independent foundation that oversees the governance of what happens at the fair, but is supported by the state and city governments of Aguascalientes.
The fair is host to a large range of activities, of which bullfighting and cockfighting are the most popular. Usually a concert is given by a prominent Mexican singer after a series of cockfights; this event tends to draw more attention than the fights themselves.
Located in the main fair venue are an assortment of sponsored stands and mechanical games, as well as stages where various concerts and theater plays are performed. The [[livestock fair]] and the ''[[charreada]]s'' still remain an important part of the celebration. Parties where traditional Mexican music is played (''tamboras'') are also celebrated on the streets of Aguascalientes. Finally, a [[casino]] is licensed in downtown Aguascalientes just for the occasion.
Concerts, art exhibits and other cultural events complement the fair in many locations around the state. The award ceremony of the National Award for Youth Art occurs in Aguascalientes during this time as well.
==History== [[Image:FNSM 14.jpg|thumb|250px|Attractions at the 2014 Fair]] The fair was celebrated for the first time around [[harvest]] time from November 5 to November 20, 1828, as a showcase of the state's produce and livestock. During that time it was in direct competition with the fairs of [[Acapulco]], [[Xalapa|Jalapa]] and [[San Juan de los Lagos]].
The celebrations centered in the ''Parián'', a market in the city of Aguascalientes, until 1848. In 1842 the outside [[balustrade]] of San Marcos Park was built in a plot of land donated by the [[Catholic Church]]. The balustrade is of [[Neoclassical architecture|Neoclassical]] style and is still preserved to this day. Once San Marcos Park was completed the date of celebration was changed to April to coincide with the festivities in honor the patron saint San Marcos.
Construction of the San Marcos Plaza [[bullring]] started in 1896 and was completed in only 48 days. From that date bullfighting was included in the festivities. It was not until 1992 that the much larger Monumental Plaza de San Marcos was built, with a [[seating capacity]] of fifteen thousand people.
Since 1924 the winner of the [[beauty pageant]] has been crowned "Queen of the Fair". In 2006, after some electoral controversy, three queens were appointed.
In 1958 the fair was elevated to the rank of "National" by [[President of Mexico|President]] [[Adolfo López Mateos]].
On April 26, 2009, the fair was canceled due to the [[2009 flu pandemic|pandemic flu virus that was afflicting certain areas of Mexico]]. This was the first time in 181 fairs that the festivities had been canceled.{{Citation needed|date=February 2015}}
==External links== *[http://www.feriadesanmarcos.gob.mx Feria Nacional de San Marcos] - Official website, in Spanish. *[http://www.aguascalientes.gob.mx Gobierno del Estado de Aguascalientes] - Government website of Aguascalientes, in Spanish.

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2014}} {{Use British English|date=March 2014}} {{Notability|date=January 2009}} [[File:Steamrally.jpg|thumb|right|Some of the many tractors at the 2008 Henham Steam Rally]] [[File:Steamrally1.jpg|thumb|One of the many steam engines at the 2008 Henham Steam Rally]]
The '''Grand Henham Steam Rally''' is held annually at the end of September at [[Henham Park]], near [[Southwold]], in the [[England|English]] county of [[Suffolk]]. It attracts a large number of exhibitors; including tractors, cars, army vehicles, fire engines, lorries and of course, steam engines. The 1975 Rally attracted approximately 200 entries whereas the current Rallies can have over 1200 entries
==History== The Henham Steam Rally really started two years before it was first held at Henham. It was first held at Lower Green Farm, [[Sotterley]]; where there was a small Steam Fair organised by Len Murray. There was another similar event held a year later in [[Brampton, Suffolk|Brampton]]. These events lacked space and it was obvious that more land and more people were needed to run the rally.
Thanks to the 4th [[Earl of Stradbroke]] the rally moved to the High Lodge area in Henham Park. The Earl also helped with funds. The main organisations involved with running the Rally are the Parochial Church Councils of Wangford-cum-Henham, [[Uggeshall]] & Sotherton; [[Wangford]] Community Council and Southwold (Sole Bay) Lions Club. They are supported by a group of volunteers and organisations who provide much needed help.
In its history at Henham, the Rally has only moved elsewhere four times. One very wet year the Rally had to be held at [[Sibton]] park near [[Yoxford]]. The 2001 Rally had to be held in a stubble field in Brampton due to the Foot & Mouth problems; Henham park being home to many sheep and cattle. In 2003 the rally was held at the [[Royal Norfolk Show]] Ground which made it easy lay out. Numbers of visitors were high as well. The 2004 Rally was held in [[Benacre, Suffolk|Benacre]] Park.<ref name="Grand Henham Steam Rally">Taken from [http://www.henhamsteamrally.co.uk/page7.htm Grand Henham Steam Rally]. 27 January 2009</ref>

[[File:Helicopter Shark Thumb.jpg|right|thumb|200px|The fake photo]] '''Helicopter Shark''' is a [[photomontage|composition of two photographs]] that gives the impression that a [[great white shark]] is leaping out of the water attacking military personnel climbing a suspended ladder attached to a [[Special Forces (United States Army)|Special Forces]] [[UH-60 Black Hawk]] helicopter. The photo was widely circulated via an [[email]] in 2001, along with a claim that it had been chosen as "[[National Geographic Society|National Geographic]] Photo of the Year". The email in question was usually written in the following form: "AND YOU THINK {{sic|YOUR}} HAVING A BAD DAY AT WORK !!" The photo is similar to an incident in the 1966 film ''[[Batman (1966 film)|Batman]]'' where a shark attacks [[Batman]] on a ladder from a helicopter. This raised suspicions that the photo in question was a [[hoax]]. ''National Geographic'' publicly disavowed the photo and the claimed award as a hoax.<ref>[http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2002/08/0815_020815_photooftheyear.html Shark "Photo of the Year" Is E-Mail Hoax], ''[[National Geographic Society|National Geographic]]'', March 8, 2005. Accessed September 11, 2007.</ref><ref name=snopes>{{cite web|url=http://www.snopes.com/photos/animals/shark.asp|title=Shark Attack|accessdate=2007-08-26|quote= |publisher=[[Snopes]]}}</ref>
The hoax has been discussed in various texts, including a marketing book to teach lessons about influence<ref>{{cite book|title=Buzz: Harness the Power of Influence and Create Demand|author=Ira Matathia and Marian L. Salzman|publisher=John Wiley and Sons|quote=At some point in 2002, you may have received an e-mail from a friend pointing you to an incredible photograph of a shark seemingly jumping out of the ocean ...|year=2003|isbn=0-471-27345-7|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sf85DYe9140C&pg=PA9&dq=helicopter+shark+photo&as_brr=0&ei=t3noRrjqA6jupQLUnsCGAw&sig=LQc6fwKm-cMl0O9QjyXXznVi03s}}</ref> and a book on teaching critical thinking.<ref>{{cite book|title=Do I Really Have to Teach Reading?: Content Comprehension, Grades 6-12|author=Cris Tovani|publisher=Stenhouse Publishers|quote=This photo has been nominated as National Geographic's Photo of the Year." "See," says Mallory. "The words say that it's a real photo." "So what? ...|year=2004|isbn=1-57110-376-7|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ous2ti3Nq7IC&pg=PT72&dq=helicopter+shark+bridge+photo&as_brr=0&ei=9KroRrxRgdKmAumJ5J4E&sig=rOe-TelOeKS_thAsSpAWmIfMlkg}}</ref>
The final edited photo was created by combining a photograph of a [[HH-60G Pave Hawk]] helicopter taken by Lance Cheung for the [[United States Air Force]] (USAF), and a photo taken by South African photographer Charles Maxwell. While the helicopter photo was in fact taken in front of the [[Golden Gate Bridge]], the photo of the shark was actually taken in [[False Bay]], [[South Africa]].<ref>{{cite news|first=Dylan Loeb|last=McClain|authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Compressed Data; Another Big Fish Story Comes Unraveled.|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9D04EEDE123BF934A35753C1A9649C8B63|quote=A photograph circulating on the Internet purports to show a great white shark leaping out of the water at a military diver hanging on a ladder from a hovering helicopter. A caption accompanying the photograph says: Although this looks like a picture taken from a Hollywood movie, it is in fact a real photo, taken near the South African coast during a military exercise by the British Navy. It has been nominated by National Geographic as 'the photo of the year.'|publisher=[[New York Times]]|date=October 7, 2002|accessdate=2008-03-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Great White internet hoax drives huge sales of photo| quote=... the shark was photographed By Mr Maxwell at [[False Bay]], [[South Africa]], and the helicopter was captured on film in [[San Francisco]], right next to the [[Golden Gate Bridge]] ...|publisher=Sunday Territorian|date=June 26, 2006}}</ref>

{{good article}} {{Infobox military person | name = Husayn ibn Hamdan | native_name = | native_name_lang = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = | death_date = October/November 918 | birth_place = | death_place = Baghdad | placeofburial = | placeofburial_label = | allegiance = [[File:Black flag.svg|22px]] [[Abbasid Caliphate]] | branch = | serviceyears = 895–915 | battles = | battles_label = | relations = [[Hamdan ibn Hamdun]] (father), [[Abdallah ibn Hamdan]] (brother), [[Nasir al-Dawla]] and [[Sayf al-Dawla]] (nephews) }} '''Husayn ibn Hamdan ibn Hamdun ibn al-Harith al-Taghlibi''' was an early member of the [[Hamdanid dynasty|Hamdanid]] family, who distinguished himself as a general for the [[Abbasid Caliphate]] and played a major role in the Hamdanids' rise to power among the Arab tribes in the [[al-Jazira, Mesopotamia|Jazira]]. Husayn entered caliphal service in 895, and through his co-operation with the caliphal government, he established himself and his family as the leader of the Arabs and Kurds of the Jazira, leading his troops to successful campaigns against the [[Qarmatians]], [[Dulafids]] and [[Tulunids]] over the next few years. As one of the most distinguished generals of the Abbasid Caliphate, he rose in power and influence until 908, when he was one of the leading conspirators in the abortive coup against Caliph [[al-Muqtadir]]. Although the coup failed and Husayn was forced to flee the capital, he soon secured a pardon and served as governor in [[Jibal]], where he again distinguished himself in military operations in south-central Iran. In ca. 911, he was appointed governor in [[Mosul]], where he remained until rising in revolt in 914/5, for reasons that are unclear. Defeated and captured in 916, he was imprisoned in [[Baghdad]], where he was executed in 918. Through his influence, the family rose to high offices, beginning a long period during which Mosul and the entire Jazira were ruled by the Hamdanids. His nephews, [[Nasir al-Dawla]] and [[Sayf al-Dawla]], went on to establish autonomous emirates in Mosul and [[Aleppo]] respectively. == Biography == === Origin and early career === [[File:Hamdanid family tree.svg|thumb|300px|Family tree of the Hamdanid dynasty]] Husayn was a son of the [[Hamdanid dynasty|Hamdanid]] family's patriarch, [[Hamdan ibn Hamdun]]. His family belonged to the [[Banu Taghlib]] tribe, established in the [[al-Jazira, Mesopotamia|Jazira]] since before the [[Muslim conquests]]. In a pattern repeated across the [[Abbasid Caliphate]], the Taghlibi leaders took advantage of the collapse of central caliphal authority of the during the decade-long [[Anarchy at Samarra]] (861–870) to assert increasing control over their particular area, centred on [[Mosul]].Kennedy (2004), pp. 265–266 Hamdan established himself among the leading tribal leaders during this time, and led the resistance against caliphal attempts to restore direct control, even allying with the [[Kharijite Rebellion (866–896)|Kharijite rebels]] in the 880s. Finally, in 895 Caliph [[al-Mu'tadid]] launched a determined attack to recover the Jazira. Hamdan fled before the Caliph's advance and was captured after a long pursuit and thrown in prison.Kennedy (2004), p. 266Canard (1971), p. 126 Husayn, however, who had been entrusted with the fortress of Ardumusht on the left bank of the [[Tigris]], chose to surrender it instead, and offered his services to the Caliph. He managed to capture the Kharijite leader [[Harun al-Shari]], thereby bringing an end to the Kharijite revolt in the Jazira. In exchange he secured not only a pardon for his father, but also the lifting of a tribute that the Taghlib had been forced to pay, and the right to form a regiment of 500 Taghlibi cavalry at government expense.Canard (1971), pp. 619–620Kennedy (2004), pp. 182, 266 This was a major success, laying the groundwork for his own and his family's ascent to power. In the words of the Islamic scholar [[Hugh N. Kennedy]],
to the caliph he offered a group of experienced warriors under his own skilled and loyal leadership; to the Taghlib, and other people in the Jazira, he offered the prospect of salaries and booty; and to his own family military command and the opportunity of acquiring wealth in government services. It was in fact not as an independent tribal leader, but rather as an intermediary between government and the Arabs and Kurds of the Jazira that al-Husayn made the family fortune.
=== In Abbasid service === [[File:Al-Jazira.svg|thumb|right|300px|Map of the [[al-Jazira, Mesopotamia|Jazira]] (Upper [[Mesopotamia]]), the homeland and main power base of the Hamdanids]] Husayn led his Taghlibi regiment with distinction over the next few years. He fought against the [[Dulafid]] [[Bakr ibn Abd al-Aziz ibn Ahmad ibn Abi Dulaf]] in the [[Jibal]] in 896. After 903 he played a decisive role in the campaigns of [[Muhammad ibn Sulayman al-Katib]] against the [[Qarmatians]] of the [[Syrian desert]], where his experienced cavalry was crucial in countering the highly mobile Qarmatians. In 903 he participated in Muhammad's [[Battle of Hama|major victory]] over the Qarmatian leader [[al-Husayn ibn Zikrawayh]], better known by his ''[[laqab]]'' of "''Sahib al-Shama''", near [[Hama]]. The Qarmatian leaders fled to the desert, but were soon captured, and brought in triumph to Baghdad.Kennedy (2004), pp. 184, 266–267, 286 Husayn then participated as commander of the vanguard in Muhammad's 904–905 campaign that ended the [[Tulunid]] dynasty and restored [[Bilad al-Sham|Syria]] and [[medieval Egypt|Egypt]] to direct caliphal control. Muhammad ibn Sulayman reportedly offered him the governorship of Egypt, but Husayn refused, preferring to return to [[Baghdad]] with the enormous booty he had collected.Kennedy (2004), pp. 184–185 On his return from Egypt, in 905–906, Husayn was sent against the [[Banu Kalb]] of Syria, who had risen in revolt at the instigation of the Qarmatians. Although he drove them into the desert, the Kalbis filled up the wells as they retreated, and he was unable to follow them. As a result, the rebels were able to reach the Lower [[Euphrates]], where they defeated another Abbasid force at al-Qadisiyya and raided the ''[[hajj]]'' caravan of the [[Mecca]] pilgrims (late 906). In the end, the forces of the central government defeated the Qarmatians and drove them to flight. On their retreat back to Syria along the Euphrates, they were attacked and annihilated by Husayn in March/April 907. Although these victories did not entirely remove the Qarmatian threat—the Qarmatians based in [[Bahrain (region)|Bahrayn]] continued to remain active and raided lower Iraq—they signalled the near-eradication of the sect from Syria.Kennedy (2004), p. 185 Husayn then subdued the remaining Kalbi rebels between the Euphrates and [[Aleppo]], and in 907–908 confronted and drove back into Syria the [[Banu Tamim]] who had invaded the Jazira seeking pillage, defeating them near Khunasira. By 908, this distinguished service had established Husayn as "one of the leading generals" (Kennedy) in the Caliphate, and enabled him to advance his own brothers to positions of power: they received various offices, the most important of which was the award of the governorship of Mosul to Husayn's brother [[Abdallah ibn Hamdan|Abu'l-Hayja Abdallah]] in 905.Kennedy (2004), p. 267 In December 908, Husayn became involved in a palace plot to depose the new Caliph, [[al-Muqtadir]], in favour of the older [[Ibn al-Mu'tazz]]. Along with two others, on 17 December 908 he attacked and killed the [[vizier]] [[al-Abbas ibn al-Hasan al-Jarjara'i]], who had endorsed al-Muqtadir's accession. The conspirators then sought to kill the young caliph as well, but the latter had barricaded himself in the Hasani Palace. Ibn al-Mu'tazz was proclaimed as caliph, and Husayn went to the palace to persuade al-Muqtadir to surrender. However, the unexpected resistance of the palace servants under the chamberlains Sawsan, [[Mu'nis al-Fahl]] and [[Mu'nis al-Khadim]], and the plotters' indecision, doomed the coup. Al-Muqtadir prevailed, and Husayn fled from Baghdad to Mosul and to [[Balad, Iraq|Balad]]. He then spent some time wandering with his followers across the Jazira. The caliph sent Husayn's own brother, Abu'l-Hayja Abdallah, to pursue him, but Husayn managed to surprise and defeat him. This success encouraged him to contact the new vizier, [[Ali ibn al-Furat]], through the mediation of his brother Ibrahim. Although he had been a leading figure in the conspiracy, and most of the other participants in the coup were executed or imprisoned, Husayn succeeded in receiving a pardon. He was not welcomed back to Baghdad, however, but appointed governor of [[Qumm]] and [[Kashan]] in the Jibal. As governor, he aided Mu'nis al-Khadim in his campaign against the [[Saffarid]] [[al-Layth ibn Ali]] in [[Sijistan]] and [[Fars Province|Fars]], and later against the former Saffarid general and rebel [[Subkara]] and his lieutenant al-Qattal. The Abbasid forces under Mu'nis al-Khadim succeeded in suppressing the rebellion by 910/1, with al-Qattal being captured by Husayn in person, according to a celebratory poem by the later Hamdanid poet [[Abu Firas]]. Abu Firas further reports that Husayn was offered the governorship of Fars, but refused, and returned to Baghdad. Ibn al-Furat, who probably still mistrusted his intentions, promptly dispatched him to the governorship of the [[Diyar Rabi'a]], the province encompassing the eastern Jazira, including Mosul. From this post, Husayn led a raiding campaign against the [[Byzantine Empire]] in 913/4. Soon after, however, an open rift developed between Husayn and the vizier [[Ali ibn Isa al-Jarrah]]. The reason is unclear, but revolved around the finances of Husayn's province. In 914/5 he rose in open rebellion, assembling a force of 30,000 Arabs and Kurds in the Jazira, a testament to his influence there. He managed to defeat a caliphal army sent against him, but when confronted by the redoubtable Mu'nis al-Khadim, recalled from Egypt, he was defeated and captured in February 916 while trying to flee north into [[Armenian Highland|Armenia]]. He was brought to Baghdad, where he was publicly paraded across the city in ritual humiliation, riding a camel and wearing a cap of shame. He was put into prison, and executed in October/November 918 on the caliph's orders. The reason for Husayn's execution is unclear. The historian of the Hamdanid dynasty, [[Marius Canard]], suggested that it may have been due to his involvement in a [[Shi'a]]-inspired conspiracy, possibly connected to the dismissal of Ibn al-Furat from his second vizierate at the same period, or with the rebellion of the autonomous governor of [[Adharbayjan]], [[Yusuf ibn Abi'l-Saj]], whom al-Muqtadir may have suspected of ties with the imprisoned Husayn. As Canard writes, "in any case the caliph must have feared that if Husayn were released he would once again start a revolt, either through a desire for independence or as a Shi'i. In order to avoid attempts by those (probably numerous) who desired his release to secure it by force, the caliph preferred to take a measure which put a stop to all intrigue". Despite Husayn's rebellion and execution, the Hamdanid family continued to prosper: his brothers were soon released from captivity, and Abdallah rose to prominence by aligning himself with Mu'nis al-Khadim and sharing in the ups and downs of the court politics in Baghdad. It was Abdallah's two sons, however, al-Hasan and Ali, better known by their honorific titles [[Nasir al-Dawla]] and [[Sayf al-Dawla]], who established the family as the ruling dynasty in the semi-independent emirates of Mosul (until 978) and Aleppo (until 1002) respectively.Kennedy (2004), pp. 267–282Canard (1971), pp. 126–131 == Character and assessment == According to Canard, Husayn "stands out more clearly than the supreme commander Mu'nis or any other military leaders" of the period for his ability and valour, as well as for his restive and ambitious spirit. He was also singled out in being of Arab descent, an unusual case among the Caliphate's senior leaders of the period. Canard assesses him as unusually open-minded, and attuned to the ideological turmoil and ferment in the Muslim world of his time, as indicated by his contact with the [[Sufi]] mystic [[al-Hallaj]], who dedicated a work on politics to Husayn. Indeed, according to Canard, Husayn's espousal of Shi'ism, and his participation in the abortive coup of 908, can best be seen in light of a desire—typical of Shi'a sympathisers—for a renewal of the Caliphate and the establishment of an "ideal Muslim government", something which the corrupt and decadent Abbasids were no longer capable of. Finally, although it fell to his brother to found the actual Hamdanid dynasty, it was Husayn who first gave his family a taste of power and glory, for which he was later celebrated in the poetry of Abu Firas. == References == {{reflist|25em}} == Bibliography == * {{EI2 | volume = 3 | title=Ḥamdānids | first = Marius | last = Canard | authorlink = Marius Canard | pages = 126–131 | url = http://referenceworks.brillonline.com/entries/encyclopaedia-of-islam-2/hamdanids-COM_0259}} * {{EI2 | volume = 3 | title=Ḥusayn b. Ḥamdān | first = Marius | last = Canard | authorlink = Marius Canard | pages = 619–620 | url = http://referenceworks.brillonline.com/entries/encyclopaedia-of-islam-2/h-usayn-b-h-amda-n-SIM_2981}} * {{cite book | title=The Prophet and the Age of the Caliphates: The Islamic Near East from the 6th to the 11th Century | edition = Second | last=Kennedy| first=Hugh N. | authorlink=Hugh N. Kennedy | year=2004 | publisher=Pearson Education Ltd. | location=Harlow, UK |isbn=0-582-40525-4 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=Wux0lWbxs1kC}} {{Hamdanid dynasty}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Husayn Ibn Hamdan}} [[Category:9th-century births]] [[Category:918 deaths]] [[Category:Abbasid generals]] [[Category:Executed military personnel]] [[Category:Hamdanid dynasty|Husayn]] [[Category:History of Iraq]] [[Category:Iraqi Shia Muslims]] [[Category:Abbasid governors]] [[Category:10th-century executions]] [[Category:People executed by the Abbasid Caliphate]] [[Category:9th-century Arabs]] [[Category:10th-century Arabs]] [[Category:Rebellions against the Abbasid Caliphate]] [[Category:Abbasid people of the Arab–Byzantine wars]] [[Category:Jibal]]
