{{Infobox news event | title = | image = Jan Kuciak portrait.jpg | image_name = | image_size = | caption = Murdered journalist Ján Kuciak. | date = 21 February 2018{{Cite news|url=https://www.irozhlas.cz/zpravy-svet/nove-poznatky-o-vrazde-jana-kuciaka_1803261414_miz|title=Prokurátor: Čas Kuciakovy vraždy známe s přesností na pět minut. Byla zřejmě na objednávku|work=iROZHLAS|access-date=2018-03-26|language=cs}} | filmed by = | participants = | outcome = Resignation of Prime Minister [[Robert Fico]], and [[Fico's Third Cabinet|his cabinet]] | reported injuries = | reported death(s) = Ján Kuciak (27)
Martina Kušnírová (27) | reported missing = | reported property damage = | burial = [[Gregorovce]] (Kušnírová)
[[Štiavnik]] (Kuciak) | inquiries = | inquest = | coroner = | suspects = [['Ndrangheta]] crime syndicate | charges = | verdict = | convictions = | publication bans = | litigation = | awards = | url = | website = | notes = }} '''Ján Kuciak''' (17 May 1990 – 21 February 2018) was a [[Slovak people|Slovak]] [[Investigative journalism|investigative journalist]]. Kuciak worked as a reporter for the news website [[Aktuality.sk]], focused mainly on investigating [[tax fraud]] of several businessmen with connections to top-level Slovak politicians.{{cite news|last1=Cameron|first1=Rob|title=Slovakia grapples with murdered journalist's last story|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-43226567|accessdate=28 February 2018|agency=BBC|date=28 February 2018|language=English}} He and his fiancée, Martina Kušnírová, were shot dead in February 2018 in their home in [[Veľká Mača]], [[Galanta District]], [[Slovakia]]. Kuciak was the first journalist murdered in Slovakia since the country's independence.{{cite web|last1=Nicholson|first1=Tom|title=Slovakian journalism’s darkest day|url=https://www.politico.eu/article/jan-kuciak-gorilla-slovakia-journalist-dead-darkest-day/|publisher=[[Politico.eu]]}} The murders caused shock and disbelief throughout the country, sparking mass popular protests and a [[political crisis]],{{cite news|last1=Madshus|first1=Karin|title=Land i sjokk etter drap på ung journalist og hans forlovede. Milliondusør utloves for tips i saken|url=https://www.dagbladet.no/nyheter/land-i-sjokk-etter-drap-pa-ung-journalist-og-hans-forlovede-milliondusor-utloves-for-tips-i-saken/69561842|accessdate=1 March 2018|language=Norwegian}} with the government of Prime Minister [[Robert Fico]] on one side, and President [[Andrej Kiska]] and opposition parties on the other.{{cite news|last1=Vonsak|first1=Martin|title=Minúta po minúte: Prokurátor obviňuje Kaliňáka a Počiatka z legalizačnej schémy|url=https://domov.sme.sk/c/20776202/online-minuta-po-minute-politicka-kriza-kuciak-vrazda-novinara-vlada-opozicia-kiska.html|accessdate=8 March 2018|agency=SME.sk}} The crisis culminated on 15 March with the resignation of Prime Minister Fico and his entire cabinet.{{cite news|title=Pellegrini is the new PM|url=https://spectator.sme.sk/c/20781796/pellegrini-is-the-official-candidate-for-the-new-pm.html|accessdate=15 March 2018|agency=Spectator.sk}} In September 2018, Slovak police stated that Kuciak was murdered because of his investigative work, and that the murder had been ordered.{{Cite news|url=https://domov.sme.sk/c/20768704/reportera-jana-kuciak-zavrazdili-v-jeho-dome.html|title=Investigatívneho reportéra Jána Kuciaka zavraždili, zrejme v súvislosti s jeho prácou|last=a.s.|first=Petit Press|work=domov.sme.sk|access-date=2018-09-28|language=sk}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.irozhlas.cz/zpravy-svet/identikit-vrazda-na-objednavku-jan-kuciak_1809171354_lac|title=Prokuratura: Jána Kuciaka zavraždili kvůli práci. Hledáme muže, který by mohl mít informace|work=iROZHLAS|access-date=2018-09-28|language=cs}} They arrested eight suspects,{{Cite news|url=https://www.irozhlas.cz/zpravy-svet/novinar-jan-kuciak-kusnirova-ukladna-vrazda-slovensko-policie-vazba-zadrzeni_1809281429_pla|title=Tři z osmi zadržených při razii v kauze Kuciak byli obviněni z úkladné vraždy|work=iROZHLAS|access-date=2018-09-28|language=cs}} charging three of them with first-degree murder. == Background == Jan Kuciak was born on 17 May 1990 in the village of [[Štiavnik]] in [[Bytča District]]. He studied and graduated with a masters degree in [[journalism]] at the [[University of Constantine the Philosopher]] in [[Nitra]], where he continued his studies as a post-graduate student in the field of [[Mass media|mass media communication]]. While working on his [[PhD]], he also held a teaching position at the same faculty.{{cite news|last1=Čunderlíková|first1=Jana|title=Skromný, pracovitý, čestný. Ján Kuciak očami jeho študentov|url=https://www.aktuality.sk/clanok/568283/skromny-pracovity-cestny-jan-kuciak-ocami-jeho-studentov/?AT=wgt.article_clanok-podclankom.c.x...B.|accessdate=8 March 2018|agency=Aktuality.sk|date=28 February 2018}} He later started to work for the newspaper ''[[Hospodárske noviny]]'', before taking up a position in the editorial office of Aktuality.sk, primarily as an investigative journalist. He focused in particular on [[tax evasion]], including cases related to the ruling [[Direction - Social Democracy]] party headed by Prime Minister Robert Fico. He had previously written about companies with unclear ownership as well as suspected systemic embezzlement from [[European Union]] funds.{{cite news|last1=Editorial Board|title=A muckraking journalist is murdered in Slovakia|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/a-muckraking-journalist-is-murdered-in-slovakia/2018/03/07/96a42c32-2174-11e8-86f6-54bfff693d2b_story.html|accessdate=9 March 2018|agency=[[The Washington Post]]|date=7 March 2018}} In the last article published before his death, on 9 February 2018, he wrote about businessman [[Marián Kočner]], who first became known in Slovakia in 1998 due to his unsuccessful attempt to take over the private television news network [[TV Markíza]] with the help of the [[Slovenská informačná služba|State Intelligence Service]] (SIS). Kuciak had previously detailed in his articles how Kočner was involved in an elaborate [[VAT]] tax fraud scheme. According to Kuciak's investigation, Kočner was buying and selling luxury apartments to himself, sometimes at the symbolic rate of €1, defrauding the state of substantial tax revenue. Kočner then allegedly began to threaten Kuciak and his family. Kuciak filed a criminal complaint against Kočner in September 2017, but according to Kuciak, no police officer was assigned to the case in 44 days since the complaint was made.{{cite news|title=UPDATED: Marches for murdered journalist will be on Friday|url=https://spectator.sme.sk/c/20770091/marches-for-murdered-journalist-will-be-on-friday.html|accessdate=8 March 2018|agency=Spectator.sk}} == Assassination == At the time of his death, Kuciak was 27 years old. He lived in the village of Veľká Mača, about 65 km (40 miles) east of the capital [[Bratislava]]. On the morning of 26 February, police were called to his home by family members after the couple had not answered phone calls for more than four days.{{cite news|title=Slovakia shocked by killing of journalist and partner|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-43202124|accessdate=1 March 2018|agency=BBC News}} Kuciak's fiancée, Martina Kusnirova, usually spoke with her mother on a daily basis. Her mother stated that she last spoke with her daughter in the afternoon of 21 February. When she tried to contact her again that evening, there was no reply. The family stated that Kusnirova's cellphone appeared to switch off three days later, probably due to a dead battery.{{cite news|last1=Cermakova|first1=Judita|title=Bratia zastrelenej Martiny: Namiesto svadby vybavujeme pohreb|url=https://presov.korzar.sme.sk/c/20769263/bratia-zastrelenej-martiny-namiesto-svadby-vybavujeme-pohreb.html|accessdate=14 March 2018|agency=Korzar}} Police entering the house found Kuciak and Kušnírová shot dead. Kuciak had been shot twice in the chest, while Kušnírová had been shot once in the head from the front. Both were shot at close range with a [[9 mm caliber]] handgun. There was no evidence of a struggle and nothing appeared to have been stolen. Police found two empty cartridges at the crime scene as well as several unused bullets. The murders were initially believed to have been committed sometime between February 22 and 25,{{cite news|title=UPDATED: Investigative journalist killed in his house|url=https://spectator.sme.sk/c/20768866/investigative-journalist-and-fiancee-killed-in-their-house.html|accessdate=1 March 2018|agency=Spectator.sk}} but were subsequently suspected to have taken place in the evening of February 21.{{cite news|title=Circumstances indicate that Kuciak’s and Kušnírová’s deaths were a contract killing|url=https://spectator.sme.sk/c/20790208/circumstances-indicate-that-kuciaks-and-kusnirovas-deaths-were-a-contract-killing.html?ref=av-right|accessdate=28 March 2018|agency=Spectator.sk}} == Reactions == [[File:Brno, Nechceme zpět 90. léta, pochod za Jána a Martinu 2018-03-02 (4467).jpg|300px|thumb|A march for Ján and Martina in Brno]] The murders sent shockwaves throughout Slovakia. The day after the news broke, gatherings were held around the country in tribute. Candles were lit at the [[SNP Square (Bratislava)|Slovak National Uprising Square]] in Bratislava and in front of the editorial office of Aktuality.sk, where Kuciak worked. Similar gatherings were also organised in the [[Czech Republic|Czech]] cities of [[Prague]] and [[Brno]].{{cite news|title=Slovaks and Czechs pay tribute to the murdered journalist|url=https://spectator.sme.sk/c/20769513/slovaks-and-czechs-pay-tribute-to-the-murdered-journalist.html|accessdate=1 March 2018|agency=Spectator.sk}} President Andrej Kiska stated that he was "shocked and horrified that something like this happened in Slovakia". The President of the European Parliament, [[Antonio Tajani]], called on Slovakia to launch a thorough investigation, offering international support if needed, adding that "the [[European Parliament]] will not rest until justice is done".{{cite news|last1=Rezaian|first1=Jason|title=Police believe a journalist was killed for reporting on fraud in the heart of Europe|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2018/02/26/police-believe-a-journalist-was-killed-for-reporting-on-fraud-in-the-heart-of-europe/|accessdate=9 March 2018|agency=[[The Washington Post]]|date=26 February 2018}} [[Ringier AG|Ringier Axel Springer]], the parent company of Aktuality.sk, called the murders a "cruel assassination", vowing to redouble their journalistic efforts. === Protests === [[File:Bratislava protest.jpg|thumb|For decent Slovakia protest in Bratislava, 16 March 2018]] On Friday, 2 March, up to 25,000 people protested in Bratislava against the attacks.{{cite news|title=Deloire: Bratislava is the capital of press freedom today|url=https://spectator.sme.sk/c/20772206/deloire-bratislava-is-today-the-capital-of-press-freedom.html|accessdate=4 March 2018|agency=Spectator.sk}} On 9 March, protests were held in 48 towns and cities in Slovakia as well as 17 other cities around the world. In Bratislava alone, about 60,000 people held a protest march, the biggest turnout of any demonstration since the [[Velvet Revolution]] in 1989.{{cite news|title=Zažili sme najväčšie protesty od roku 1989|url=https://www.aktuality.sk/clanok/571169/online-protesty-po-vrazde-jana-kuciaka-a-martiny-kusnirovej/|accessdate=9 March 2018|agency=Aktuality.sk|date=9 March 2018|language=Slovak}} The protests were endorsed by several universities in Slovakia and the Czech Republic, teachers, school associations, artists and non-governmental organisations. 21 universities cancelled afternoon lectures to allow students and employees to attend the protests.{{cite news|title=Enough of Fico, thousands of people shouted at gatherings across Slovakia|url=https://spectator.sme.sk/c/20777059/enough-of-fico-thousands-of-people-shouted-at-gatherings-across-slovakia.html|accessdate=9 March 2018|agency=Spectator.sk|ref=2march}} Two days after Prime Minister Fico's resignation, an even larger demonstration was held in Bratislava with over 65,000 people participating under slogans such as "Enough of Smer" and "Early elections". Former Speaker of Parliament and ex-presidential candidate [[František Mikloško]] made an impassioned speech during the protest saying that "the revolution started by the parents has to be finished by their children". He argued that only twice in the history of post-war [[Czechoslovakia]] have popular protests managed to make the government resign: in November 1989 and now, adding that "when somebody tries to abuse their power in the future, they should remember March 2018 and the mass protests". Mikloško's speech was accompanied by the ringing of keys, reminiscent of the Velvet Revolution in 1989.{{cite news|title=Enough of Smer, people chanted in streets|url=https://spectator.sme.sk/c/20782425/enough-of-smer-people-chanted-in-streets.html|accessdate=17 March 2018|agency=Spectator.sk|date=16 March 2018}} == Investigation == In a press conference the same morning, [[Police of Slovakia|Slovak Police]] President [[Tibor Gašpar]] stated that the murders "likely have something to do with [Kuciak’s] investigative activities".{{cite news|last=Boffey|first=Daniel|title=Slovakian journalist investigating claims of tax fraud linked to ruling party shot dead|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/26/slovakian-journalist-investigating-claims-of-tax-linked-to-ruling-party-shot-dead|accessdate=26 February 2018|work=[[The Guardian]]}}{{cite web|title=Investigative journalist Jan Kuciak killed in Slovakia|url=http://www.dw.com/en/investigative-journalist-jan-kuciak-killed-in-slovakia/a-42745005|publisher=[[Deutsche Welle]] |date=2018-02-26 |language=en}}{{cite web|last=Janicek|first=Karel|title=Slovak investigative reporter, girlfriend found shot dead|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/europe/slovak-investigative-reporter-his-girlfriend-killed/2018/02/26/6b9fec6e-1adb-11e8-98f5-ceecfa8741b6_story.html|publisher=[[The Washington Post]]}} The [[Fico's Third Cabinet|Government of Slovakia]] offered €1 million for information leading to the murderers. Prime Minister [[Robert Fico]] made the announcement during a press conference with Interior Minister [[Robert Kaliňák]] and Police President Tibor Gašpar.{{cite news|title=Jan Kuciak murder: Slovak PM offers €1m reward in appeal|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-43220275|accessdate=1 March 2018|agency=BBC News}} During the press conference, described by critics as "surreal" and "bizarre", they displayed packs of banknotes amounting to one million euros, which the government promised to give to anyone who came forward with relevant information that could help explain the murder.{{cite news|title=Fico stands by Trošková|url=https://spectator.sme.sk/c/20770106/fico-stands-by-troskova.html|accessdate=1 March 2018|agency=Spectator.sk}} Furthermore, Prime Minister Fico announced the creation of an inter-agency task force involving employees of the General Prosecutor’s Office, Special Prosecutor’s Office, the Interior Ministry and the SIS in attempting to solve the case. At the time of his murder, Kuciak was working on a report about Slovak connections with the [[Italy|Italian]] [[organized crime syndicate]] [['Ndrangheta]].{{cite web|url=https://spectator.sme.sk/c/20769558/kuciak-investigated-links-between-politicians-and-mafia.html|title=Kuciak investigated links between politicians and mafia|first=Petit Press |last=a.s.|publisher=}} He had previously reported on organized tax fraud involving businesspeople close to the ruling [[Smer-SD]] party.{{cite news|title=Kuciak investigated links between politicians and mafia|url=https://spectator.sme.sk/c/20769558/kuciak-investigated-links-between-politicians-and-mafia.html|accessdate=1 March 2018}} On 28 February, Aktuality.sk published Kuciak's last, unfinished story.{{cite web|last1=Kuciak|first1=Ján|title=Talianska mafia na Slovensku. Jej chápadlá siahajú aj do politiky|url=https://www.aktuality.sk/clanok/568007/talianska-mafia-na-slovensku-jej-chapadla-siahaju-aj-do-politiky/|website=Aktuality.sk|accessdate=1 March 2018|language=Slovak}} The article details the activities of Italian businessmen with ties to organised crime who have settled in eastern Slovakia, and have spent years embezzling European Union funds intended for the development of this relatively poor region, as well as their connections to high-ranking state officials, such as [[Viliam Jasaň]], a deputy and the Secretary of the State Security Council of Slovakia, or {{ill|Mária Trošková|sk}}, a former nude model who became Chief Adviser of Prime Minister Robert Fico. Both Jasaň and Trošková took leave of absence on the same day, stating that they would return to their positions once the investigations were concluded.{{cite news|title=Trošková and Jasaň are leaving their posts at Government’s Office|url=https://spectator.sme.sk/c/20770917/troskova-and-jasan-are-leaving-their-posts-at-governments-office.html|accessdate=1 March 2018|agency=Spectator.sk}} [[File:Za slušné Slovensko, Košice 1.jpg|thumb|Protest in [[Košice]], 9 March 2018]] === Initial arrests === On 1 March, four days after the discovery of the murders, heavily armed units from the Slovak Police Corps' elite National Crime Agency (NAKA) raided several locations in eastern Slovakia, in the cities of [[Michalovce]] and [[Trebišov]].{{cite news|last1=Jabrik|first1=Peter|title=Polícia udrela na východe. Pozrite si raziu na Zemplíne|url=https://dolnyzemplin.korzar.sme.sk/c/20771327/policia-udrela-na-vychode-pozrite-si-raziu-na-zempline.html|accessdate=1 March 2018}} Antonino Vadalà, an Italian businessman mentioned in Kuciak's report, was detained along with his two brothers Sebastiano and Bruno, as well as his cousin Pietro Caprotta and several other men of Italian origin.{{cite web|title=Polícia pri razii na východe Slovenska zadržala podnikateľa z Kuciakovho článku|url=https://www.aktuality.sk/clanok/568661/policia-vykonava-raziu-na-vychode-slovenska-u-podnikatela-z-kuciakovho-clanku/|publisher=Aktuality.sk|accessdate=1 March 2018|language=Slovak}} All the detained men were released from custody after 48 hours, due to lack of sufficient evidence.{{cite news|title=Police release all seven detained Italians|url=https://spectator.sme.sk/c/20772816/police-release-all-seven-detained-italians.html|accessdate=4 March 2018}} On the day of the arrests, General Prosecutor Jaromír Čižnár ordered the police to give no further updates to the press or the public regarding the investigation.{{cite news|title=More concerns about independence of Kuciak murder investigation|url=https://spectator.sme.sk/c/20773539/more-concerns-about-independence-of-kuciak-murder-investigation.html|accessdate=9 March 2018|agency=Spectator.sk|date=1 March 2018}} Vadala was rearrested on 13 March, this time due to an international warrant issued by the Italian police.{{cite news|title=Italian entrepreneur Vadala reportedly detained due to drugs|url=https://spectator.sme.sk/c/20779976/italian-entrepreneur-vadala-reportedly-detained-due-to-drugs.html|accessdate=13 March 2018}} According to the arrest warrant, Vadala is suspected of drug trafficking as well as money laundering. Among other offences, he was said to have been planning to import large quantities of cocaine from South America. On 23 April, Slovakia approved Italy's request for extradition.{{cite news|title=Slovakia to extradite Vadala to Italy for prosecution|url=https://spectator.sme.sk/c/20810188/slovakia-to-extradite-vadala-to-italy-for-prosecution.html|accessdate=5 May 2018}} As a result of their investigation into the murder, the Slovak police stated that Kuciak had been murdered because of his work as an investigative journalist, and that the murder had been ordered.{{Cite news|url=https://domov.sme.sk/c/20768704/reportera-jana-kuciak-zavrazdili-v-jeho-dome.html|title=Investigatívneho reportéra Jána Kuciaka zavraždili, zrejme v súvislosti s jeho prácou|last=a.s.|first=Petit Press|work=domov.sme.sk|access-date=2018-09-28|language=sk}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.irozhlas.cz/zpravy-svet/identikit-vrazda-na-objednavku-jan-kuciak_1809171354_lac|title=Prokuratura: Jána Kuciaka zavraždili kvůli práci. Hledáme muže, který by mohl mít informace|work=iROZHLAS|access-date=2018-09-28|language=cs}} In late September 2018, eight suspects were arrested,{{Cite news|url=https://www.irozhlas.cz/zpravy-svet/novinar-jan-kuciak-kusnirova-ukladna-vrazda-slovensko-policie-vazba-zadrzeni_1809281429_pla|title=Tři z osmi zadržených při razii v kauze Kuciak byli obviněni z úkladné vraždy|work=iROZHLAS|access-date=2018-09-28|language=cs}} though the police suggested that the person who had ordered the killing was not among them, and is unknown.{{Cite news|url=https://www.irozhlas.cz/zpravy-svet/jan-kuciak-vrazda-podezreli-policejni-razie-zatceni_1809270712_dbr|title=Policie zatkla podezřelé z vraždy Jána Kuciaka a jeho partnerky, informují slovenská média|work=iROZHLAS|access-date=2018-09-28|language=cs}} Three of those arrested were later charged with first-degree murder. == Political crisis == The same day the murder was announced, Prime Minister Fico called on the political opposition not to "exploit" the situation. Meanwhile, a number of opposition politicians accused the ruling Smer-SD party of indirect involvement. Member of Parliament Veronika Remišová, from the opposition [[Ordinary People (Slovakia)|OĽaNO]] party, compared the killings to the infamous murder of [[Róbert Remiáš]], a police officer who was assassinated in 1996, in an act widely believed to have been a contract killing by the [[Slovak mafia]] on the orders of Prime Minister [[Vladimír Mečiar]].{{cite news|title=Fico odmieta zneužívanie tragickej vraždy Kuciaka na politický boj|url=https://domov.sme.sk/c/20768892/politici-odsudili-vrazdu-investigativneho-novinara-kuciaka.html|accessdate=13 March 2018|agency=Sme.sk}} On 27 February, [[Freedom and Solidarity]] and OL'aNO demanded the resignation of Interior Minister Robert Kaliňák and Police President Tibor Gašpar.{{cite news|title=Opozícia spúšťa petíciu za odstúpenie Kaliňáka a policajného šéfa|url=https://domov.sme.sk/c/20769995/olano-a-sas-obvinuju-politikov-smeru-z-napojenie-na-taliansku-mafiu.html|accessdate=13 March 2018|agency=SME.sk}} [[File:Protest po vražde Jána Kuciaka a Martiny Kušnírovej, 9. marca 2018.jpg|thumb|Protest in Bratislava, 9 March 2018]] [[File:VENUES OF BRATISLAVA SUMMIT 16.September 2016 (29073567594).jpg|thumb|Interior Minister [[Robert Kaliňák]] speaking with Prime Minister [[Robert Fico]] ]] The crisis escalated on 4 March when President Kiska made a live broadcast on state television, warning the government against further polarising the country. He called for either a "radical cabinet reshuffle" or a [[snap election]].{{cite news|title=UPDATED: Fico won't step down, accuses Kiska of joining opposition|url=https://spectator.sme.sk/c/20773344/kiska-government-reshuffle-or-early-elections.html|accessdate=13 March 2018|agency=Spectator.sk}} The president's speech infuriated Fico, who accused Kiska of "joining the opposition". Furthermore, he accused the president of conspiring with Hungarian-American billionaire [[George Soros]] in the planning of a [[coup d'etat]], based on the fact that President Kiska met with Soros at Soros' apartment in [[New York City]] in September 2017, ostensibly to discuss issues related to the [[Romani people|Roma minority]].{{cite news|title=Fico steers conversation to Soros, saying he will deal with politics later|url=https://spectator.sme.sk/c/20774275/fico-mentions-soros-says-he-will-deal-with-politics-later.html|accessdate=13 March 2018|agency=Spectator.sk}} On 28 February, two days after the news of Kuciak's murder broke, Minister of Culture [[Marek Maďarič]] announced his resignation.{{cite web|title=Vražda Kuciaka: Jasaň a Trošková opustí úřad vlády, ministr kultury Maďarič odstoupil|url=http://www.ceskatelevize.cz/ct24/svet/2404909-slovensky-ministr-kultury-madaric-odstoupil-k-demisi-se-rozhodl-kvuli-vrazde-kuciaka|publisher=ČT24|language=Czech}} Announcing his decision to the press, Madaric stated that "as a culture minister, I can't cope with the fact that a journalist was killed during my tenure."{{cite news|last1=Balogova|first1=Beata|title=Maďarič zrušil Fica aj jeho refrén|url=https://komentare.sme.sk/c/20770729/madaric-zrusil-fica-a-jeho-refren-ze-niet-dovodov-na-zodpovednost.html|accessdate=28 February 2018|agency=SME}}{{cite news|title=Culture Minister Maďarič resigns|url=https://spectator.sme.sk/c/20770743/culture-minister-madaric-resigns.html|accessdate=1 March 2018}} [[Robert Kaliňák]], Minister of the Interior and Deputy Prime Minister, resigned on 12 March 2018 after weeks of mounting pressure.{{cite web|last1=Dedinský|first1=Matej|title=Minister Kaliňák podáva demisiu|url=https://www.aktuality.sk/clanok/571728/minister-kalinak-podava-demisiu/|publisher=Aktuality.sk|language=Slovak}} The [[Most-Hid]] party, the junior coalition partner in the government, had demanded the resignation of Kalinak in exchange for continued support of Smer-SD.{{cite news|title=Slovakia journalist murder: Interior minister resigns|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-43371821|accessdate=12 March 2018|agency=BBC News}} The next day, Most-Hid joined the calls for snap elections, announcing that it would leave the government if it failed to reach a deal with its two coalition partners, Smer-SD and the [[Slovak National Party]] (SNS). Most-Híd Chairman, [[Béla Bugár]], announced the decision after an eight-hour session of the Most-Hid Republican Council, the party's decision-making body.{{cite news|title=Most-Híd calls for early elections|url=https://spectator.sme.sk/c/20779611/most-hid-calls-for-early-elections.html|accessdate=13 March 2018|agency=Spectator.sme.sk}} === Fico resigns === On 14 March, following a meeting with President Kiska, Prime Minister Fico announced that he would resign as Prime Minister to avoid [[Next Slovak parliamentary election|early elections]] and "solve the political crisis".{{cite news|last1=Terenzani|first1=Michaela|title=UPDATED: Fico is ready to resign tomorrow|url=https://spectator.sme.sk/c/20781295/fico-is-ready-to-resign-tomorrow.html|accessdate=14 March 2018}} During the meeting, Fico laid out a number of specific conditions to be met by the President in order for him to resign, including that the result of the [[Slovak parliamentary election, 2016|2016 Slovak parliamentary election]] be respected, that the current ruling government coalition must continue, and that Smer-SD, as the largest party in parliament, would name the next Prime Minister. Fico stated that he already had a candidate in mind, widely reported in Slovak media as Deputy Prime Minister [[Peter Pellegrini]].{{cite news|title=Minúta po minúte: Fico podá demisiu, novým premiérom môže byť Pellegrini |url=https://domov.sme.sk/c/20780574/online-vladna-kriza-pokracuje.html?ref=st-bno-1|accessdate=14 March 2018|agency=Sme.sk}} On 15 March, President Kiska formally accepted the resignation of Fico and his cabinet, and tasked Pellegrini with the forming of a new government. == See also == *[[Daphne Caruana Galizia]], Maltese investigative journalist murdered in 2017 *[[List of journalists and media workers killed in Mexico]] *[[Assassination of Róbert Remiáš]] == References == {{reflist|2}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kuciak ,Ján}} [[Category:2018 controversies]] [[Category:2018 deaths]] [[Category:2018 in Slovakia]] [[Category:2018 murders in Europe]] [[Category:Deaths by firearm in Slovakia]] [[Category:February 2018 crimes in Europe]] [[Category:Murder in Slovakia]] [[Category:Murdered journalists]] [[Category:Slovak journalists]] [[Category:Slovak murder victims]] [[Category:Killed journalists in Slovakia]] [[Category:2018 protests]]

A '''[[referendum]] on [[electoral reform]]''' was supposed to be held in the [[province (Canada)|province]] of '''[[New Brunswick]]''', [[Canada]] on '''May 12, 2008'''. The date was announced by [[Premier of New Brunswick|Premier]] [[Bernard Lord]] on June 20, 2006 in announcing his response to the 2004 report of the [[Commission on Legislative Democracy]]. However, Lord and his [[Progressive Conservative Party of New Brunswick|Progressive Conservatives]] were defeated in the [[New Brunswick general election, 2006|September 2006 election]] and the new [[New Brunswick Liberal Association|Liberal]] government, which had always expressed skepticism about the model proposed by the Commission and its mandate opted not proceed with a referendum in an announcement on June 28, 2007.<ref>http://www.gnb.ca/cnb/news/ex/2007e0859ex.htm</ref>
The proposal was on a [[mixed member proportional representation]] system which would see 36 members elected to the [[Legislative Assembly of New Brunswick]] in [[first past the post]] single member [[Riding (division)|riding]]s and 20 additional members elected from 4 regions, using closed lists, to ensure proportionality. The threshold for proportional representation seats would be 5% of the provincial vote.
In October 2010, after the 2010 New Brunswick election, the group [[New Brunswickers For Proportional Representation]] was formed to push for the implementation of proportional representation as outlined by the Commission on Legislative Democracy.

It is one of the band's biggest hits, and was released as the second single from the band's 1992 debut studio album, ''[[Core (Stone Temple Pilots album)|Core]]''. ==Composition and inspiration== The song's chord structure was inspired by Robert DeLeo's love of [[ragtime]] music, and its lyrics were loosely based on a newspaper article Scott Weiland had read about a girl who had been found dead after having been kidnapped in the early 1990s. Weiland had also said that the song's lyrics are a metaphor for a failed relationship.{{Cite magazine |last=Prato |first=Greg |date=2012-06-13 |title=Plush |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/plush-stone-temple-pilots |magazine=Rolling Stone}} ==Reception== The song was released in 1992 as ''Core'''s second single and became a major rock radio hit in the U.S., peaking at #1 on the [[Album Rock Tracks]] and #9 on the [[Modern Rock Tracks]]. The song was also one of the first alternative rock songs to reach the #1 spot on the [[Album Rock Tracks]] chart during height of the alternative rock/grunge scene. "Plush" won in the category of "[[Grammy Award for Best Hard Rock Performance|Best Hard Rock Performance]]" at the [[Grammy Awards of 1994|1994 Grammy Awards]]. The music video also earned the band an [[MTV Video Music Award for Best New Artist]] in 1993. "Plush" remains one of the biggest rock hits of the 1990s, and is still commonly heard on radio stations today. The song also was voted #12 on the [[Australians|Australian]] annual music poll [[Triple J Hottest 100]] in [[Triple J Hottest 100, 1993|1993]]. In 2004, this song was featured in ''[[Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas]]'' soundtrack on [[Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas soundtrack#Radio X|Radio X]]. The song also appeared as a playable song in the music video games ''[[Rock Band 3]]'' and ''[[Power Gig: Rise of the SixString]]'' in addition to the VH1 series ''[[Hindsight (TV series)|Hindsight]]''. ==Music video== The award-winning [[music video]], directed by [[Josh Taft]], was released in 1993 and had heavy rotation on [[MTV]]. It combines a visual interpretation of the song's lyrics with footage of a red-haired Weiland singing with the band as a lounge act in an empty bar. There are two different versions of this video, with minor but very noticeable differences. For example, in the version that appears on the ''[[Thank You (Stone Temple Pilots album)|Thank You]]'' Bonus DVD, the last shot of the video is a woman looking at a mirror image of herself and viewing her whole body while the mirror image drifts away. In another version, she's looking at a mirror image of her face, with water (possibly rain) dripping down the reflection of the mirror. ==Acoustic version== Weiland and Stone Temple Pilots guitarist [[Dean DeLeo]] performed an impromptu acoustic version of "Plush" on the [[MTV]] show ''[[Headbangers Ball]]'' in 1992. The recording was originally only available on a CD single from the United Kingdom for their single, "[[Creep (Stone Temple Pilots song)|Creep]]", and on the German promotional radio release "Plush (unplushed)", but it was not officially released anywhere else until it appeared on the band's 2003 "greatest hits" compilation, ''[[Thank You (Stone Temple Pilots album)|Thank You]]'', alongside the original studio recording. Like its original version, it also became a big hit to rock and alternative radio stations in 2003 (despite not charting on any U.S. or international charts) although it had moderate airplay when the original version had heavy airplay on radio at the time. A rare first take of the same acoustic version on MTV's Headbangers Ball was also available, but it was only found as a B-side to the rare "[[Crackerman]]" single. This version was notable for being a longer version of the one which appeared on "Thank You". It has the same length and processing as the original electric version, and also uses the last part of the original electric version. Although most radio stations play the original acoustic version, few radio stations also managed to play the rare acoustic version. ==Track listing== #"Plush" [Edit] – 4:19 #"Sin" – 6:05 #"Sex Type Thing (Swing Type Version)" – 4:20 #"Sex Type Thing (Live on the Word)" – 3:32 ==Charts== {| class="wikitable" !Chart (1993) !Peak

revision.text:
{{pp-semi|small=yes}} {{Infobox film | name = Pocahontas II:
Journey to a New World | image = PIIJTANW.jpg | caption = The DVD Cover | director = {{Plainlist| * Tom Ellery * [[Bradley Raymond]]}} | producer = Leslie Hough | writer = {{Plainlist| * [[Allen Estrin]] * Cindy Marcus * Flip Kobler }} | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Irene Bedard]] * [[Billy Zane]] * [[Jim Cummings]] * [[Donal Gibson]] * [[David Ogden Stiers]] * [[Linda Hunt]] * [[Jean Stapleton]] * [[Russell Means]] * [[Finola Hughes]] * [[Brad Garrett]] }} | music = {{Plainlist| * [[Lennie Niehaus]] (film score composer) * Blaise Tosti * Stacy Widelitz * [[Larry Grossman (composer)|Larry Grossman]] * [[Marty Panzer]] (lyrics) }} | studio = [[DisneyToon Studios|Walt Disney Video Premiere]]
[[Walt Disney Animation Australia]]
[[Walt Disney Animation Canada]]
[[Walt Disney Animation Japan]] | distributor = [[Walt Disney Home Video]] | released = {{start date|1998|8|25}}https://www.amazon.com/Pocahontas-II-Journey-New-World/dp/0788811002 | runtime = 72 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = }} '''''Pocahontas II: Journey to a New World''''' is a 1998 [[direct-to-video|straight-to-video]] sequel to the 1995 [[Disney]] film ''[[Pocahontas (1995 film)|Pocahontas]]''. While the first film dealt with her meeting with John Smith and the arrival of the British settlers in Jamestown, the sequel focuses on Pocahontas's journey to England with John Rolfe to negotiate for peace between the two nations, although her death is omitted from the film's ending. ==Plot== In London, [[John Smith (explorer)|John Smith]] is ambushed by a group of soldiers with a warrant for his arrest and presumed dead in the ensuing confrontation; [[John Ratcliffe (governor)|Governor Ratcliffe]] has lied to [[James VI and I|King James]] (being a personal friend of the King) and framed Smith as the traitor from the first film in a plot to declare war against the [[Powhatan]] Nation and get ahold of the gold he still believes them to possess, all while avoiding punishment for his own crimes. In order to prevent this, the King sends a young diplomat, [[John Rolfe]], to bring [[Chief Powhatan]] to England for negotiations. In the New World, [[Pocahontas (character)|Pocahontas]], Powhatan's daughter, mourns John Smith's death but is eventually able to move on. John Rolfe soon arrives, greeted by English civilians (who by now have settled in [[Jamestown, Virginia|Jamestown]]) and a curious Pocahontas. Rolfe eventually speaks with Powhatan, but he refuses to accompany him to England, so Pocahontas goes in her father's stead, believing that she can bring about peace between the two nations. Powhatan sends a bodyguard, Uttamatomakkin (Uti) to accompany Pocahontas. Rolfe and Pocahontas have a rocky start, but gradually warm up to each other. In England, Rolfe leaves Pocahontas at his mansion and meets with King James and [[Anne of Denmark|Queen Anne]], but James refuses to meet with Pocahontas despite Rolfe's pleas. Instead, per Ratcliffe's suggestion, James invites both Rolfe and Pocahontas to an upcoming ball and promises that if Pocahontas impresses him by acting "civilised", he will prevent the armada from sailing to Jamestown, but if she does not, he will declare war. Knowing that Ratcliffe deliberately manipulated the King, Rolfe and his maid, Mrs. Jenkins, educate Pocahontas in the ways of British etiquette to prepare her. At the ball, Pocahontas wins over the King and Queen with flattery and almost manages to prevent war, but a bear-baiting arranged by Ratcliffe and greatly enjoyed by the snobbish nobility infuriates Pocahontas and she openly accuses the King of savage behaviour. James angrily orders Pocahontas and Uti imprisoned in the Tower of London, and declares war on the Powhatan tribe. At his home, a despondent Rolfe is approached by a hooded stranger who helps him break Pocahontas and Uti out of the tower and take them to an inn, where the man reveals himself to be John Smith. Smith implores Pocahontas to stay hidden with him, but she instead takes Rolfe's advice and decides to try and stop the war one last time. She openly confronts the King in the palace and reveals Smith, thus proving that Ratcliffe had been lying the entire time. Realizing Ratcliffe's treachery, James sends a battalion (consisting of Pocahontas, Smith, Rolfe, Uti, and their animal friends) to stop the armada. They are successful in stopping the ships before they can set sail, but Ratcliffe refuses to give up and tries to kill Pocahontas. Smith appears and fights Ratcliffe one-on-one until Ratcliffe draws a gun, but before he can fire, Rolfe sends him overboard with the ship's mast. Ratcliffe makes it back to the port, where he is arrested by the King. Smith receives a royal pardon and his own ship from the King as a sign of apology. Pocahontas and Rolfe, meanwhile, appear on the verge of admitting that they love each other. Before they can, Smith appears and implores Pocahontas to accompany him on his new journeys around the world, but Pocahontas chooses otherwise and she and Smith part ways as friends. As Pocahontas later prepares to return to Jamestown, she finds Rolfe waiting for her on the ship, having chosen to go and live with her in Jamestown (with Uti remaining in London in his stead). They kiss as the ship sails into the sunset. ==Cast== * [[Irene Bedard]] ([[Judy Kuhn]] singing) as '''[[Pocahontas (character)|Pocahontas]]''': the main character. Desiring everlasting peace between England and her people, she travels to London as a diplomat, falling in love with John Rolfe on the way. * [[Billy Zane]] as '''[[John Rolfe]]''': the diplomat sent to bring Chief Powhatan to England and who falls in love with Pocahontas to the point that he stands up against Ratcliffe and King James. * [[Donal Gibson]] as '''[[John Smith (explorer)|Captain John Smith]]''': Pocahontas's one time love, presumed dead after a confrontation with Ratcliffe. He later resurfaces to aid Pocahontas and John Rolfe against Ratcliffe. Gibson replaces his older brother, [[Mel Gibson|Mel]], who voiced Smith in the first film. * [[David Ogden Stiers]] as '''[[John Ratcliffe (governor)|Governor Ratcliffe]]''': the main villain. Having lied to King James about the events in Jamestown, Ratcliffe becomes more determined than ever to go to war with the Powhatans in order to find his falsely speculated treasure, even if it means influencing the King. * [[John Kassir]] as '''Meeko''': Pocahontas's pet raccoon, ever looking for fun. * [[Russell Means]] as '''[[Chief Powhatan]]''': Pocahontas's father and chief of the Powhatans. He refuses to travel to England, so Pocahontas goes in his stead. * [[Frank Welker]] as '''Flit''': Pocahontas's hummingbird friend, now warmer towards strangers than before. * [[Linda Hunt]] as '''Grandmother Willow''': Pocahontas's spiritual guardian. She advises Pocahontas to go to England for peace. * [[Danny Mann]] as '''Percy''': once Ratcliffe's pet dog, now living with Pocahontas and Meeko in Jamestown. * [[Michelle St. John]] as '''Nakoma''': Pocahontas's best friend, now married to a Powhatan who somewhat resembles Kocoum. * [[Jim Cummings]] as '''[[James VI and I|King James]]''': King of England. While well-meaning, he is portrayed as a simple-minded buffoon who is very easily manipulated by Ratcliffe. * [[Finola Hughes]] as '''[[Anne of Denmark|Queen Anne]]''': James's wife, somewhat more intelligent and open than her husband. * [[Jean Stapleton]] as '''Mrs. Jenkins''': John Rolfe's well-meaning housemaid. * [[Brad Garrett]] as '''[[Tomocomo|Uttamatomakkin]]''': Pocahontas's bodyguard, sent by Powhatan to watch over her. His nickname is "Uti". == Reception == On [[Rotten Tomatoes]], the film holds an [[approval rating]] of 29% based on 7 reviews, with an [[average rating]] of 4.4/10.{{cite web|url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/pocahontas_ii_journey_to_a_new_world/|title=Pocahontas II: Journey to a New World (1998)|publisher=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|accessdate=April 10, 2018}} David Keyes from ''Cinemaphile'' rated the movie with 3/4 saying: "Normally, I'd refuse to review such a sequel, but this attention must be paid here, because the original "''Pocahontas''" movie was not that great. Usually, a Disney sequel jumps back a step or two from its predecessors, as it did with "''Aladdin''". "''Pocahontas II: Journey To A New World''" does not–it stays at the same level of the original, by creating entertaining and colorful new characters which have usually been the best things about Disney animated movies." Keyes went on to criticize the historical inaccuracy of the film.{{cite web|last=Keyes |first=David |title=Pocahontas II |url=http://www.cinemaphile.org/reviews/1998/pocahontas2.html |publisher=Cinemaphile |date=September 2, 1998 |accessdate=April 10, 2016}} ''The Movie Report'' rates the movie with 2 out of 4 stars writing: "While ''Journey to a New World'' is the best of the crop of Disney's direct-to-video animation sequels, it's still a slapdash effort, with none of gorgeous colors and animation of the first film, and little of its emotional resonance."{{cite web|title=Pocahontas II: Journey to a New World|url=http://themoviereport.com/movierpt38.html#poca2|publisher=The Movie Report|accessdate=April 10, 2016}} ==Music== The soundtrack of the movie was released on November 23, 2009, from the [[Walt Disney Records]].{{cite web|title= Pocahontas II: Journey To A New World|url=https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B002X2ZRFG?ie=UTF8&*Version*=1&*entries*=0|publisher=Amazon|accessdate=April 10, 2016}} #Where Do I Go From Here? – Sung by Pocahontas ([[Judy Kuhn]]) #What a Day in London – Sung by Pocahontas (Judy Kuhn) #Wait 'Till He Sees You – Sung by Mrs. Jenkins and John Rolfe (Jean Stapleton and Billy Zane) #Things Are Not What They Appear- Sung by Radcliffe (David Ogden Stiers) #Between Two Worlds – Sung by Pocahontas and John Rolfe (Judy Kuhn and Billy Zane) ==References== ==External links== {{Portal|Disney|Film in the United States|1990s|Cartoon}} * {{Official website|http://movies.disney.com/pocahontas-2-journey-to-a-new-world}} * {{Bcdb title|7261}} * {{Amg movie|168218}} * {{IMDb title|0143808}} {{Pocahontas}} {{Bradley Raymond}} {{Disney direct-to-video animated features}} [[Category:1998 films]] [[Category:1998 animated films]] [[Category:1998 direct-to-video films]] [[Category:1990s American animated films]] [[Category:1990s biographical films]] [[Category:1990s musical films]] [[Category:1990s romance films]] [[Category:1990s sequel films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American biographical films]] [[Category:American sequel films]] [[Category:Animation based on real people]] [[Category:Animated musical films]] [[Category:Direct-to-video sequel films]] [[Category:Pocahontas (franchise)]] [[Category:Disney direct-to-video animated films]] [[Category:DisneyToon Studios animated films]] [[Category:Films scored by Lennie Niehaus]] [[Category:Films about Native Americans]] [[Category:Films about interracial romance]] [[Category:Films directed by Bradley Raymond]] [[Category:Films set in the 1610s]] [[Category:Films set in England]] [[Category:Films set in London]] [[Category:Films set in the Thirteen Colonies]] [[Category:Films set in Virginia]] [[Category:Films set in the Powhatan Confederacy]] [[Category:Musical films based on actual events]]

'''Queshuachaca''' (possibly from [[Quechua language|Quechua]] ''q'iswa'' a rope of twisted dried maguey or [[Jarava ichu|ichhu]], ''chaka'' bridge, "rope bridge", also spelled ''Keshwa Chaca, Q'iswa Chaca, Keswachaka, Q'eshwachaka, Qeswachaka, Q'eswachaca, Q'eswachaka, Queshuachaca, Queswachaka''), consisting of ropes made of grass and spanning the [[Apurimac River]] near Huinchiri, in [[Quehue District]], [[Canas Province]], [[Peru]], is the last remaining [[Inca rope bridge]].[http://www.slate.com/articles/life/world_of_wonders/2011/02/the_last_incan_grass_bridge.html "The Last Incan Grass Bridge"], Joshua Foer, Feb. 22, 2011, slate.com Even though there is a modern bridge nearby, the residents of the region keep the ancient tradition and skills alive by renewing the bridge annually, in June. Several family groups have each prepared a number of grass-ropes to be formed into cables at the site, others prepare mats for decking, and the reconstruction is a communal effort. In ancient times the effort would have been a form of tax, with participants coerced to perform the rebuilding; nowadays the builders have indicated that effort is performed to honor their ancestors and the [[Mama Pacha|Pachamama]] (Earth Mother). The event has also been supported by video productions for [[Nova (TV series)|Nova]] and the [[BBC]] and is the subject of an independent documentary titled ''The Last Bridge Master'' (in-production, 2014). It is becoming a minor tourist attraction, with some small tolls charged for tourists to use the road during the festival to walk the newly completed bridge. In 2009 the government recognized the bridge and its maintenance as part of the cultural heritage of Peru, and there is now some outside sponsorship.[http://translate.google.co.nz/translate?hl=en&sl=es&u=http://globedia.com/inc-declara-patrimonio-cultural-inmaterial-puente-eswachaka-cusco&prev=/search%3Fq%3DDeclara%2BPatrimonio%2BCultural%2Bde%2Bla%2BNaci%25C3%25B3n%2Bal%2Britual%2Bde%2Breconstrucci%25C3%25B3n%2Bdel%2Bpuente%2BQ%2527eswachaka,%2Bdel%2Bdistrito%2Bde%2BQuehue,%2Bprovincia%2Bde%2BCanas,%26hl%3Den%26safe%3Dactive%26client%3Dfirefox-a%26hs%3Dezm%26tbo%3Dd%26rls%3Dorg.mozilla:en-US:official&sa=X&ei=7k0GUZG1OauUiQf8_4C4BQ&ved=0CEAQ7gEwAg (automated translation)] of http://globedia.com/inc-declara-patrimonio-cultural-inmaterial-puente-eswachaka-cusco The current lead bridge engineer is [[Victoriano Arizapana]]. == Renewing the bridge == File:IRB-1-OldBridgeSags-keshwa3h.jpg|

[https://archive.is/20070113202043/http://www.equnaytra.sy/ eQunaytra] |footnotes = }} '''Quneitra''' (also '''Al Qunaytirah''', '''Qunaitira''', or '''Kuneitra'''; {{lang-ar|القنيطرة}} ''al-Qunayṭrah''){{Pronunciation needed}} is the largely destroyed and abandoned [[Capital (political)|capital]] of the [[Quneitra Governorate]] in south-western [[Syria]]. It is situated in a high valley in the [[Golan Heights]] at an elevation of 1,010 metres (3,313 feet)<ref name="bromiley"/> above sea level. Since 1974, pursuant to [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 350]] and the [[Agreement on Disengagement between Israel and Syria|Agreement on Disengagement]] between [[Israel]] and Syria, the city is inside the [[United Nations|UN]]-patrolled the [[United Nations Disengagement Observer Force|buffer zone]].
Quneitra was founded in the [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman era]] as a way station on the caravan route to [[Damascus]] and subsequently became a garrison town of some 20,000 people. In 1946, it became part of the independent Syrian Republic within the Riff Dimashq Governorate and in 1964 became the capital of the split Quneitra Governorate.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.statoids.com/usy.html|title=Syria Provinces|website=www.statoids.com|access-date=2016-06-29}}</ref> On 10 June 1967, the last day of the [[Six-Day War]], Quneitra came under Israeli control.<ref>On 10 June, Israeli authorities utilized a [[postmark]], in Arabic, English and Hebrew, for mail sent from Quneitra. Livni, Israel. ''Encyclopedia of Israel Stamps.'' Tel Aviv: Sifriyat Ma'arit, 1969. p.195</ref> It was briefly recaptured by Syria during the 1973 [[Yom Kippur War]], but Israel regained control in its subsequent counter-offensive. The city was almost completely destroyed before the Israeli withdrawal in June 1974. Syria had refused to rebuild the city and actively discouraged resettlement in the area. Israel was heavily criticized by the [[United Nations]] for the city's destruction,<ref name="ungar3240">"[http://www.unhcr.org/refworld/docid/3b00f1c74.html Report of the Special Committee to Investigate Israeli Practices Affecting the Human Rights of the Population of the Occupied Territories]", United Nations General Assembly Resolution 3240, 29 November 1974, A/RES/3240, [https://unispal.un.org/UNISPAL.NSF/0/5B1BC7E46C040DF7852560DE0054E654 unispal] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110103082535/http://unispal.un.org/UNISPAL.NSF/0/5B1BC7E46C040DF7852560DE0054E654 |date=2011-01-03 }}.</ref> while Israel has also criticized Syria for not rebuilding Quneitra.<ref>Abraham Rabinovich. ''The Yom Kippur War'', 492. Knopf Publishing Group, 2005. {{ISBN|0-8052-1124-1}}</ref> During the [[Syrian Civil War]], Quneitra became a clash point between rebel forces and Syrian Arab Army. {{As of|2014}}, it became controlled by the [[Syrian opposition]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2014/09/syria-golan-rebels-attack-control-quneitra.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-10-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141025154857/http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2014/09/syria-golan-rebels-attack-control-quneitra.html |archivedate=2014-10-25 |df= }}</ref>
In 2004, its population was estimated at 153 persons, with some 4,000 more living in the surrounding areas of the former city.
Between 2014 and July 2018 Quneitra was ''[[de facto]]'' controlled by the [[Southern Front (Syrian rebel group)|Southern Front]]. By the end of July, 2018, Syrian Government forces regained control over the city.<ref name=syriahr2018/><ref name=Reuter2018/>
==Etymology== Qantara is the Arabic word for arched bridge.<ref name="Rajki">András Rajki, [https://archive.org/download/ArabicEtymologicalDictionary Arabic Dictionary with etymologies], 2005, accessed 5 September 2018</ref><ref>{{cite web |title= Syria Gate: all about Syria (official government website) |url= http://www.syriagate.com/Syria/about/cities/Quneitra/ |accessdate= 2009-11-19 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081221221152/http://www.syriagate.com/Syria/about/cities/Quneitra/ |archivedate= 2008-12-21 |df= }}</ref> Quneitra means small arch or bridge, and the name is derived from the small-arches bridge around which the town has been built.<ref>Ahron Bregman, [https://books.google.com/books?id=ew1PAgAAQBAJ&pg=PT84 Cursed Victory: A History of Israel and the Occupied Territories], Penguin, 2014</ref>
==Political status== {{Further information|International law and the Arab-Israeli conflict}} Quneitra is the capital of the [[Quneitra Governorate]], a district of southwestern Syria that incorporates the whole of the Golan Heights. The city of Quneitra is within the portion of the Golan Heights controlled by Syria.<ref name="eb"/> [[Madinat al-Baath]] (Baath City), also known as New Quneitra, replaced Quneitra as the administrative centre of Quneitra Governorate.<ref name=reuters20141120>{{cite news |title=Syrian insurgents attack government-held town near Israel |first=Suleiman |last=Al-Khalidi |url= http://uk.reuters.com/article/2014/11/20/uk-mideast-crisis-south-idUKKCN0J422U20141120 |newspaper=Reuters |date=20 November 2014 |accessdate=18 June 2015}}</ref>
==Geography and demographics== [[File:Golan heights rel89-orig.jpg|right|thumb|Map of the Golan Heights as of 1989, illustrating the location of Quneitra and the surrounding area.]] Quneitra is situated in a high valley in the Golan Heights at an altitude of {{convert|942|m|abbr=off}} [[above sea level]]. It is overshadowed to the west by the Israeli-held portion of the Golan Heights and the peak of [[Mount Bental|Har Bental]]. The surrounding area is dominated by ancient volcanic lava flows interspersed by a number of dormant [[volcanic cone]]s which rise some {{convert|150|to|200|m|abbr=off}} above the surrounding plain. The volcanic hills of the region have played a key role as observation points and natural firing positions in the conflicts over the region, most notably in the Yom Kippur War.<ref>Simon Dunstan. ''The Yom Kippur War 1973: The Sinai'', p. 9. Osprey Publishing, 2003. {{ISBN|1-84176-220-2}}</ref> In more peaceful times, the fertile volcanic soil has supported agricultural activities such as [[wheat]] growing and [[pastoralism]].<ref name="bromiley">Geoffrey William Bromiley. "Golan", in ''International Standard Bible Encyclopedia: E-J'', p. 520. Wm. B. Eerdmans Publishing, 1994. {{ISBN|0-8028-3782-4}}</ref>
Writing during the inter-war period, the American traveller Harriet-Louise H. Patterson recorded that Quneitra was
{{quote|charmingly set in a grove of [[eucalyptus]] trees. Its chief claim to charm or the few moments of a traveller's time beyond passport formalities is the beautiful vista which it offers of Jordan as it flows down from Hermon through banks of tangled bush and flowering pink and white oleanders. Kuneitra is pleasant as a stopping-place for lunch. It is cool under the spreading trees, usually quiet and restful.<ref>Harriet-Louise H. Patterson, ''Around The Mediterranean With My Bible''. W. A. Wilde Co., 1941</ref>}}
The city's position on an important trade route gave it a varied population for much of its history. By the start of the 20th century it was dominated by Muslim [[Circassians in Syria|Circassian]]s from the [[Caucasus]], accompanied by [[Syrian Turkmen|Turkmen]] and [[Arabs]].<ref name="Chatty112"/><ref name="t24 turkmen"/> Its population grew to some 21,000 people, mostly [[Arab]]s, followed by [[Syrian Turkmen|Turkmen]] and [[Circassians]], following Syrian [[French Mandate of Syria|independence from France]] in 1946.<ref name="eb"/><ref name="t24 turkmen">{{cite news|url=http://t24.com.tr/haber/suriyenin-turkmenleri-ne-zaman-geldiler-nufuslari-ne-kadar-hangi-bolgelerdeler,319482|publisher=[[T24 (media)|T24]]|title=Suriye'nin Türkmenleri: Ne zaman geldiler, nüfusları ne kadar, hangi bölgelerdeler?|date=8 December 2015|accessdate=19 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://haberiniz.com.tr/haber/gundem/161836/suriye-turkmenleri-4.html|publisher=Haberiniz|title=Suriye Türkmenleri|date=3 July 2015|accessdate=19 September 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170126133049/http://haberiniz.com.tr/haber/gundem/161836/suriye-turkmenleri-4.html|archivedate=26 January 2017|df=}}</ref> After its abandonment in 1967 and subsequent destruction, its population was dispersed to other parts of Syria. The city remains abandoned apart from a residual Syrian security presence. Due to frequent and large population movements within Syria and across borders caused by war, there are no reliable population estimates available post-2011. The impact of the crisis has led to massive displacements and a gradual deterioration of access to basic services. Quneitra has also been the destination for many internally displaced persons (IDPs) from neighbouring Daraa and Rif Dimashq governorates. In August 2013, many of the estimated 75,000 IDPs from Nawa and Al-Harra in Daraa Governorate reportedly fled to Quneitra.<ref>http://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/140317%20-%20Quneitra%20Governorate%20Assessment%20Report%20-%20FINAL.pdf</ref>
